Who were " [the Chathams]348-the chathams ? "[191-abel] [Abel]191-abel wondered . [Bigwigs]1996-bigwigs , [mandarins]1997-mandarins , [he]191-abel supposed half contemptuously . [They]1998-they moved a great deal in [that world]1999-that world . [He]191-abel took it as a hint that [he]191-abel should go . [They]1998-they had come to the end of what [they]1998-they had to say to [each other]996-each other - [he]191-abel and [Digby]224-digby . [He]191-abel still hoped , however , that [he]191-abel might talk with [Eugénie]225-eugénie alone .

" About this African business - "[191-abel] [he]191-abel began , bethinking [him]191-abel of another question - when [the children]555-the children came in ; [they]555-the children had come to say good- night . [Maggie]316-maggie was wearing [his]191-abel necklace and it looked very pretty , [he]191-abel thought , or was it [she]316-maggie who looked so pretty ? But [their]555-the children frocks , [their]555-the children clean blue and pink frocks , were crumpled ; they were smudged with the sooty London leaves that [they]555-the children had been holding in [their]555-the children arms .

" [Grubby little ruffians]5367-grubby little ruffians ! "[191-abel] [he]191-abel said , smiling at [them]555-the children . " Why d'you wear [your]316-maggie best clothes to play in [the garden]5163-the garden ? "[191-abel] said [Sir Digby]224-digby , as [he]191-abel kissed [Maggie]316-maggie . [He]191-abel said it jokingly , but there was a hint of disapproval in [his]191-abel tones . [Maggie]316-maggie made no answer . [Her]316-maggie eyes were riveted on the camellia that [[her]316-maggie mother]685-her mother wore in the front of [her]685-her mother dress . [She]316-maggie went up and stood looking at [her]316-maggie .

" And [you]344-sara - what [a little sweep]5369-a little sweep ! "[224-digby] said [Sir Digby]224-digby , pointing to [Sara]344-sara .

" It 's [Maggie]316-maggie 's birthday , "[225-eugénie] said [Eugénie]225-eugénie , holding out [her]225-eugénie arm again as if to protect [the little girl]624-the little girl .

" That is a reason , [I]224-digby should have thought , "[224-digby] said [Sir Digby]224-digby , surveying [[his]224-digby daughters]674-his daughters , " to - er - to - er - reform one 's habits . "[224-digby] [He]224-digby stumbled , trying to make [his]224-digby sentence sound playful ; but it turned out as it generally did when [he]224-digby talked to [the children]555-the children , lame and rather pompous .

[Sara]344-sara looked at [[her]344-sara father]643-her father as if [she]344-sara were considering [him]224-digby .

" [To - er - to - er - reform one]5370-to - er - to - er - reform one 's habits , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara repeated . Emptied of all meaning , [she]344-sara had got the rhythm of [his]224-digby words exactly . The effect was somehow comic . [The Colonel]583-the colonel laughed ; but [Digby]224-digby , [he]224-digby felt , was annoyed . [He]224-digby only patted [Sara]344-sara on the head when [she]344-sara came to say good - night ; but [he]224-digby kissed [Maggie]316-maggie as [she]344-sara passed [him]224-digby .

" Had a nice birthday ? "[224-digby] [he]224-digby said , pulling [her]316-maggie to [him]224-digby . [Abel]191-abel made it an excuse to go .

" But there is no need for [you]191-abel to go yet , [Abel]191-abel ? "[225-eugénie] [Eugénie]225-eugénie protested as [he]191-abel held out [his]191-abel hand .

[She]316-maggie kept hold of [his]191-abel hand as if to prevent [him]191-abel from going . What did [she]316-maggie mean ? Did [she]316-maggie want [him]191-abel to stay , did [she]316-maggie want [him]191-abel to go ? [Her]316-maggie eyes , [her]316-maggie large dark eyes , were ambiguous .

" But [you]316-maggie 're dining out ? "[191-abel] [he]191-abel said .

" Yes , "[316-maggie] [she]316-maggie replied , letting [his]191-abel hand fall , and as [she]316-maggie said no more there was nothing for it , [he]191-abel supposed - [he]191-abel must take [himself]191-abel off .

" Oh , [I]191-abel can find [my]191-abel way out alone , "[191-abel] [he]191-abel said as [he]191-abel left [the room]577-the room .

[He]191-abel went [downstairs]969-downstairs rather slowly . [He]191-abel felt depressed and disappointed . [He]191-abel had not seen [her]316-maggie alone ; [he]191-abel had not told [her]316-maggie anything . Perhaps [he]191-abel never would tell [anybody]990-anybody anything . After all , [he]191-abel thought as [he]191-abel went [downstairs]969-downstairs , slowly , heavily , it was [his]191-abel own affair ; it did n't matter to [anybody else]2012-anybody else . [One]847-one must burn [one]847-one 's own smoke , [he]191-abel thought as [he]191-abel took [his]191-abel hat . [He]191-abel glanced round .

Yes . . . [the house]554-the house was full of pretty things . [He]191-abel looked vaguely at a great crimson chair with gilt claws that stood in [the hall]638-the hall . [He]191-abel envied [Digby]224-digby [[his]191-abel house]2017-his house , [[his]191-abel wife]550-his wife , [[his]191-abel children]646-his children . [He]191-abel was getting old , [he]191-abel felt . All [[his]191-abel children]646-his children were grown - up ; [they]646-his children had left [him]191-abel . [He]191-abel paused on [the doorstep]2021-the doorstep and looked out into [the street]587-the street . It was quite dark ; lamps were lit ; the autumn was drawing in ; and as [he]191-abel marched up [the dark windy street]2023-the dark windy street , now spotted with raindrops , a puff of smoke blew full in [his]191-abel face ; and leaves were falling .

1907

It was midsummer ; and the nights were hot . The moon , falling on water , made it white , inscrutable , whether deep or shallow . But where the moonlight fell on solid objects it gave them a burnish and a silver plating , so that even the leaves in [country roads]2024-country roads seemed varnished . All along [the silent country roads]2025-the silent country roads leading to [London]1-london [carts]2026-carts plodded ; the iron reins fixed in the iron hands , for vegetables , fruit , flowers travelled slowly . Heaped high with round crates of cabbage , cherries , carnations , [they]2027-they looked like caravans piled with the goods of [tribes migrating in search of water]2028-tribes migrating in search of water , driven by [enemies]2029-enemies to seek new pasturage . On [they]2027-they plodded , down [this road]2030-this road , [that road]2031-that road , keeping close to [the kerb]2032-the kerb . Even the horses , had [they]2027-they been blind , could have heard the hum of [London]1-london in the distance ; and [the drivers]2033-the drivers , dozing , yet saw through half shut eyes the fiery gauze of [the eternally burning city]2034-the eternally burning city . At dawn , at [Covent Garden]79-covent garden , [they]2027-they laid down [their]2027-they burdens ; tables and trestles , even the cobbles were frilled as with some celestial laundry with cabbages , cherries and carnations .

All the windows were open . Music sounded . From behind crimson curtains , rendered semi - transparent and sometimes blowing wide came the sound of the eternal waltz - After the ball is over , after the dance is done - like a serpent that swallowed its own tail , since the ring was complete from [Hammersmith]80-hammersmith to [Shoreditch]26-shoreditch . Over and over again it was repeated by trombones outside [public houses]1682-public houses ; [errand boys]2036-errand boys whistled it ; bands inside [private rooms where [people]503-people were dancing]2037-private rooms where people were dancing played it . There [they]2027-they sat at little tables at Wapping in [the romantic Inn that overhung [the river]813-the river]2039-the romantic inn that overhung the river , between [timber warehouses where [barges]2042-barges were moored]2041-timber warehouses where barges were moored ; and here again in [Mayfair]81-mayfair . Each table had [its]2043-its lamp ; [its]2043-its canopy of tight red silk , and the flowers that had sucked damp from the earth that noon relaxed and spread their petals in vases . [Each table]2044-each table had its pyramid of strawberries , its pale plump quail ; and [Martin]205-martin , after [India]13-india , after [Africa]14-africa , found it exciting to talk to [a girl with bare shoulders]2045-a girl with bare shoulders , to [a woman iridescent with green beetles wings in [her]2046-a woman iridescent with green beetles wings in her hair in a manner that the waltz condoned and half concealed under its amorous blandishments hair in a manner that the waltz condoned and half concealed under its amorous blandishments]2046-a woman iridescent with green beetles wings in her hair in a manner that the waltz condoned and half concealed under its amorous blandishments . Did it matter what [one]847-one said ? For [she]2046-a woman iridescent with green beetles wings in her hair in a manner that the waltz condoned and half concealed under its amorous blandishments looked over [her]2046-a woman iridescent with green beetles wings in her hair in a manner that the waltz condoned and half concealed under its amorous blandishments shoulder , only half listening , as [a man]814-a man came in wearing decorations , and [a lady , in black with diamonds]2049-a lady , in black with diamonds , beckoned [him]814-a man to [a private corner]2050-a private corner .

As the night wore on a tender blue light lay on [the market carts]2051-the market carts still plodding close to [the kerb]2032-the kerb , past [Westminster]19-westminster , past the yellow round clocks , [the coffee stalls]2053-the coffee stalls and the statues that stood there in the dawn holding so stiffly [their]2051-the market carts rods or rolls of paper . And [the scavengers]2054-the scavengers followed after , sluicing the pavements . Cigarette ends , little bits of silver paper , orange peel - all the litter of the day was swept off the pavement and still [the carts]1667-the carts plodded , and [the cabs]2056-the cabs trotted , indefatigably , along [the dowdy pavements of [Kensington]83-kensington]2057-the dowdy pavements of kensington , under the sparkling lights of [Mayfair]81-mayfair , carrying [ladies with high head dresses]2058-ladies with high head dresses and [gentlemen]2059-gentlemen in white waistcoats along [the hammered dry roads]2060-the hammered dry roads which looked in the moonlight as if [they]2060-the hammered dry roads were plated with silver .

" Look ! "[225-eugénie] said [Eugénie]225-eugénie as [the cab]708-the cab trotted over [the bridge]2062-the bridge in the summer twilight . " Is n't that lovely ? "[225-eugénie]

[She]225-eugénie waved [her]225-eugénie hand at [the water]5356-the water . [They]2064-they were crossing [the Serpentine]12-the serpentine ; but [her]225-eugénie exclamation was only an aside ; [she]225-eugénie was listening to what [[her]225-eugénie husband]1135-her husband was saying . [[Their]2064-they daughter]2066-their daughter [Magdalena]343-magdalena was with [them]2064-they ; and [she]2066-their daughter looked where [[her]2066-their daughter mother]685-her mother pointed . There was [the Serpentine]12-the serpentine , red in the setting sun ; the trees grouped together , sculptured , losing their detail ; and the ghostly architecture of [the little bridge]2068-the little bridge , white at the end , composed the scene . The lights - the sun - light and the artificial light - were strangely mixed .

" . . . of course it 's put [the Government]84-the government in a fix , "[224-digby] [Sir Digby]224-digby was saying . " But then that 's what [he]84-the government wants . "[224-digby]

" Yes . . . [he]84-the government 'll make a name for [himself]84-the government , [that young man]5371-that young man , "[341-lady pargiter] said [Lady Pargiter]341-lady pargiter .

[The cab]708-the cab passed over [the bridge]2062-the bridge . [It]708-the cab entered the shadow of the trees . Now it left [the Park]562-the park and joined the long line of cabs , taking [people in evening dress]2072-people in evening dress to plays , to dinner - parties , that was streaming towards [the Marble Arch]8-the marble arch . The light grew more and more artificial ; yellower and yellower . [Eugénie]225-eugénie leant across and touched something on [[her]225-eugénie daughter]762-her daughter 's dress . [Maggie]316-maggie looked up . [She]316-maggie had thought that [they]2074-they were still talking politics .

" So , "[685-her mother] said [[her]762-her daughter mother]685-her mother , arranging the flower in front of [her]685-her mother dress . [She]685-her mother put [her]685-her mother head a little on one side and looked at [[her]685-her mother daughter]762-her daughter approvingly . Then [she]685-her mother gave a sudden laugh and threw [her]685-her mother hand out . " D'you know what made [me]685-her mother so late ? "[685-her mother] [she]685-her mother said . " [That imp]5372-that imp , [Sally]344-sara . . . "[685-her mother]

But [[her]762-her daughter husband]1135-her husband interrupted [her]762-her daughter . [He]1135-her husband had caught sight of an illuminated clock .

" [We]2078-we shall be late , "[1135-her husband] [he]1135-her husband said .

" But eight - fifteen means eight - thirty , "[225-eugénie] said [Eugénie]225-eugénie as [they]2078-we turned down [a side street]2079-a side street .

All was silent in [the house at [Browne Street]74-browne street]2080-the house at browne street . A ray from the street lamp fell through the fanlight and , rather capriciously , lit up a tray of glasses on the hall table ; a top hat ; and a chair with gilt paws . The chair , standing empty , as if waiting for [someone]591-someone , had a look of ceremony ; as if it stood on the cracked floor of [some Italian ante - room]2082-some italian ante - room . But all was silent . [Antonio]342-antonio , [the man servant]2083-the man servant , was asleep ; [Mollie]349-mollie , [the housemaid]1914-the housemaid , was asleep ; downstairs in [the basement]521-the basement a door flapped to and fro - otherwise all was silent .

[Sally]344-sara in [[her]344-sara bedroom]2086-her bedroom at [the top of [the house]554-the house]2087-the top of the house turned on [her]344-sara side and listened intently . [She]344-sara thought [she]344-sara heard the front door click . A burst of dance music came in through the open window and made it impossible to hear .

[She]344-sara sat up in bed and looked out through the slit of the blind . Through the gap [she]344-sara could see a slice of the sky ; then [roofs]2089-roofs ; then the tree in [the garden]5163-the garden ; then the backs of [houses]1311-houses opposite standing in a long row . [One of [the houses]1569-the houses]2092-one of the houses was brilliantly lit and from the long open windows came dance music . [They]2094-they were waltzing . [She]344-sara saw shadows twirling across the blind . It was impossible to read ; impossible to sleep . First there was the music ; then a burst of talk ; then [people]503-people came out into [the garden]5163-the garden ; voices chattered , then the music began again .

It was a hot summer 's night , and though it was late , [the whole world]2097-the whole world seemed to be alive ; the rush of traffic sounded distant but incessant .

A faded brown book lay on [her]344-sara bed ; as if [she]344-sara had been reading . But it was impossible to read ; impossible to sleep . [She]344-sara lay back on the pillow with [her]344-sara hands behind [her]344-sara head .

" And [he]2098-he says , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara murmured , " [the world]5285-the world is nothing but . . . "[344-sara] [She]344-sara paused . What did [he]2098-he say ? Nothing but thought , was it ? [she]344-sara asked [herself]344-sara as if [she]344-sara had already forgotten . Well , since it was impossible to read and impossible to sleep , [she]344-sara would let [herself]344-sara BE thought . It was easier to act things than to think them . Legs , body , hands , the whole of [her]344-sara must be laid out passively to take part in this universal process of thinking which [the man]826-the man said was [the world living]2100-the world living . [She]344-sara stretched [herself]344-sara out . Where did thought begin ?

In the feet ? [she]344-sara asked . There they were , jutting out under the single sheet . They seemed separated , very far away . [She]344-sara closed [her]344-sara eyes . Then against [her]344-sara will something in [her]344-sara hardened . It was impossible to act thought . [She]344-sara became something ; a root ; lying sunk in the earth ; veins seemed to thread the cold mass ; the tree put forth branches ; the branches had leaves .

" - the sun shines through the leaves , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara said , waggling [her]344-sara finger . [She]344-sara opened [her]344-sara eyes in order to verify the sun on the leaves and saw the actual tree standing out there in [the garden]5163-the garden . Far from being dappled with sunlight , it had no leaves at all . [She]344-sara felt for a moment as if [she]344-sara had been contradicted . For the tree was black , dead black .

[She]344-sara leant [her]344-sara elbow on the sill and looked out at the tree . A confused clapping sound came from [the room]577-the room where [they]2103-they were having the dance . The music had stopped ; [people]503-people began to come down the iron staircase into [the garden]5163-the garden which was marked out with blue and yellow lamps dotted along the wall . The voices grew louder . [More people]2106-more people came and [more people]2106-more people came . [The dotted square of green]2108-the dotted square of green was full of the flowing pale figures of [women in evening dress]2109-women in evening dress ; of the upright black - and - white figures of [men in evening dress]2110-men in evening dress . [She]344-sara watched [them]2103-they moving in and out . [They]2103-they were talking and laughing ; but [they]2103-they were too far off for [her]344-sara to hear what [they]2103-they were saying . Sometimes a single word or a laugh rose above the rest , and then there was a confused babble of sound . In [[their]2103-they own garden]2111-their own garden all was empty and silent . A cat slid stealthily along the top of a wall ; stopped ; and then went on again as if drawn on some secret errand . Another dance struck up .

" Over again , over and over again ! "[344-sara] [she]344-sara exclaimed impatiently . The air , laden with the curious dry smell of London earth , puffed in [her]344-sara face , blowing the blind out . Stretched flat on [her]344-sara bed , [she]344-sara saw the moon ; it seemed immensely high above [her]344-sara . Little vapours were moving across the surface . Now they parted and [she]344-sara saw engravings chased over the white disc . What were they , [she]344-sara wondered - [mountains]2112-mountains ? [valleys]2113-valleys ? And if [valleys]2113-valleys , [she]344-sara said to [herself]344-sara half closing [her]344-sara eyes , then white trees ; then [icy hollows]2115-icy hollows , and nightingales , two nightingales calling to [each other]996-each other , calling and answering [each other]996-each other across [the valleys]2118-the valleys . The waltz music took the words " calling and answering [each other]996-each other "[344-sara] and flung them out ; but as it repeated the same rhythm again and again , it coarsened [them]2103-they , it destroyed [them]2103-they . The dance music interfered with everything . At first exciting , then it became boring and finally intolerable . Yet it was only twenty minutes to one .

[Her]344-sara lip raised itself , like that of a horse that is going to bite . The little brown book was dull . [She]344-sara reached [her]344-sara hand above [her]344-sara head and took down another book from the shelf of battered books without looking at it . [She]344-sara opened the book at random ; but [her]344-sara eye was caught by [one of [the couples who were still sitting out in [the garden]5163-the garden though [the others]535-the others had gone in]2120-the couples who were still sitting out in the garden though the others had gone in]2119-one of the couples who were still sitting out in the garden though the others had gone in . What were [they]2119-one of the couples who were still sitting out in the garden though the others had gone in saying , [she]344-sara wondered ? There was something gleaming in the grass , and , as far as [she]344-sara could see , [the black - and - white figure]2123-the black - and - white figure stooped and picked it up .

" And as [he]2123-the black - and - white figure picks it up , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara murmured , looking out , " [he]2123-the black - and - white figure says to [the lady beside [him]2123-the black - and - white figure]5375-the lady beside him : Behold , [Miss Smith]350-miss smith , what [I]344-sara have found on the grass - a fragment of [my]344-sara heart ; of [my]344-sara broken heart , [he]2123-the black - and - white figure says . [I]344-sara have found it in the grass ; and [I]344-sara wear it on [my]344-sara breast "[344-sara] - [she]344-sara hummed the words in time to the melancholy waltz music - " [my]344-sara broken heart , this broken glass , for love - "[344-sara] [she]344-sara paused and glanced at the book . On the fly - leaf was written :

" [Sara Pargiter]344-sara from [[her]344-sara Cousin]1595-her cousin [Edward Pargiter]215-edward . "[344-sara]

" . . . for love , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara concluded , " is best . "[344-sara]

[She]344-sara turned to the title - page .

" The Antigone of Sophocles , done into English verse by [Edward Pargiter]215-edward , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara read .

Once more [she]344-sara looked out of the window . [The couple]2124-the couple had moved . [They]2124-the couple were going up the iron staircase . [She]344-sara watched [them]2124-the couple . [They]2124-the couple went into [the ballroom]2125-the ballroom . " And suppose in the middle of the dance , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara murmured , ' [she]344-sara takes it out ; and looks at it and says , ' What is this ? ' and it 's only a piece of broken glass - of broken glass . . . . " [She]344-sara looked down at the book again .[344-sara]

" The Antigone of Sophocles , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara read . The book was brand - new ; it cracked as [she]344-sara opened it ; this was the first time [she]344-sara had opened it .

" The Antigone of [Sophocles]484-sophocles , done into English verse by [Edward Pargiter]215-edward , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara read again . [He]2126-he had given it [her]344-sara in [Oxford]28-oxford ; one hot afternoon when [they]2124-the couple had been trailing through [chapels]2127-chapels and [libraries]1194-libraries . " Trailing and wailing , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara hummed , turning over the pages , " and [he]2126-he said to [me]344-sara , getting up from the low armchair , and brushing [his]2126-he hand through [his]2126-he hair "[344-sara] - [she]344-sara glanced out of the window - " ' [my]344-sara wasted youth , [[my]344-sara wasted youth]5377-my wasted youth . ' "[344-sara] The waltz was now at its most intense , its most melancholy . " Taking in [his]2126-he hand , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara hummed in time to it , " this broken glass , this faded heart , [he]2126-he said to [me]344-sara . . . "[344-sara] Here the music stopped ; there was a sound of clapping ; [the dancers]2129-the dancers once more came out into [the garden]5163-the garden .

[She]344-sara skipped through the pages . At first [she]344-sara read a line or two at random ; then , from the litter of broken words , scenes rose , quickly , inaccurately , as [she]344-sara skipped . The unburied body of [a murdered man]2131-a murdered man lay like a fallen tree - trunk , like a statue , with one foot stark in the air . Vultures gathered . Down [they]2129-the dancers flopped on the silver sand . With a lurch , with a reel , the top - heavy birds came waddling ; with a flap of the grey throat swinging , [they]2129-the dancers hopped - [she]344-sara beat [her]344-sara hand on the counterpane as [she]344-sara read - to that lump there . Quick , quick , quick with repeated jerks they struck the mouldy flesh . Yes . [She]344-sara glanced at the tree outside in [the garden]5163-the garden . The unburied body of [the murdered man]2133-the murdered man lay on the sand . Then in a yellow cloud came whirling - who ? [She]344-sara turned the page quickly . Antigone ? [She]344-sara came whirling out of the dust - cloud to where the vultures were reeling and flung white sand over the blackened foot . [She]344-sara stood there letting fall white dust over the blackened foot . Then behold ! there were more clouds ; dark clouds ; [the horsemen]2134-the horsemen leapt down ; [she]344-sara was seized ; [her]344-sara wrists were bound with withies ; and [they]2134-the horsemen bore [her]344-sara , thus bound - where ?

There was a roar of laughter from [the garden]5163-the garden . [She]344-sara looked up . Where did [they]2134-the horsemen take [her]344-sara ? [she]344-sara asked . [The garden]5163-the garden was full of [people]503-people . [She]344-sara could not hear a word that [they]2134-the horsemen were saying . [The figures]2138-the figures were moving in and out .

" To [the estimable court of [the respected ruler]5379-the respected ruler]5378-the estimable court of the respected ruler ? "[344-sara] [she]344-sara murmured , picking up a word or two at random , for [she]344-sara was still looking out into [the garden]5163-the garden . [The man]826-the man 's name was [Creon]351-creon . [He]826-the man buried [her]344-sara . It was a moonlight night . The blades of the cactuses were sharp silver . [The man in the loincloth]2141-the man in the loincloth gave three sharp taps with [his]2141-the man in the loincloth mallet on the brick . [She]344-sara was buried alive . [The tomb]2142-the tomb was a brick mound . There was just room for [her]344-sara to lie straight out . Straight out in [a brick tomb]2143-a brick tomb , [she]344-sara said . And that 's the end , [she]344-sara yawned , shutting the book .

[She]344-sara laid [herself]344-sara out , under the cold smooth sheets , and pulled the pillow over [her]344-sara ears . The one sheet and the one blanket fitted softly round [her]344-sara . At the bottom of the bed was a long stretch of cool fresh mattress . The sound of the dance music became dulled . [Her]344-sara body dropped suddenly ; then reached [ground]2144-ground . A dark wing brushed [her]344-sara mind , leaving a pause ; a blank space . Everything - the music , the voices - became stretched and generalised . The book fell on the floor . [She]344-sara was asleep .

" It 's a lovely night , "[2145-the girl who was going up the iron steps with her partner] said [the girl who was going up the iron steps with [[her]2145-the girl who was going up the iron steps with her partner partner]2146-her partner]2145-the girl who was going up the iron steps with her partner . [She]344-sara rested [her]344-sara hand on the balustrade . It felt very cold . [She]344-sara looked up ; a slice of yellow light lay round the moon . It seemed to laugh round it . [[Her]2145-the girl who was going up the iron steps with her partner partner]2146-her partner looked up too , and then mounted another step without saying anything for [he]2146-her partner was shy .

" Going to the match tomorrow ? "[2146-her partner] [he]2146-her partner said stiffly , for [they]2148-they scarcely knew [each other]996-each other .

" If [[my]2145-the girl who was going up the iron steps with her partner brother]5380-my brother gets off in time to take [me]2145-the girl who was going up the iron steps with her partner , "[2145-the girl who was going up the iron steps with her partner] [she]2145-the girl who was going up the iron steps with her partner said , and went up another step too . Then , as [they]2148-they entered [the ballroom]2125-the ballroom , [he]2146-her partner gave [her]2145-the girl who was going up the iron steps with her partner a little bow and left [her]2145-the girl who was going up the iron steps with her partner ; for [[his]2146-her partner partner]2151-his partner was waiting .

The moon which was now clear of clouds lay in a bare space as if the light had consumed the heaviness of the clouds and left [a perfectly clear pavement]2152-a perfectly clear pavement , [a dancing ground for revelry]2153-a dancing ground for revelry . For some time the dappled iridescence of the sky remained unbroken . Then there was a puff of wind ; and a little cloud crossed the moon .

There was a sound in [the bedroom]737-the bedroom . [Sara]344-sara turned over .

" Who 's that ? "[344-sara] [she]344-sara murmured . [She]344-sara sat up and rubbed [her]344-sara eyes .

It was [[her]344-sara sister]615-her sister . [She]344-sara stood at the door , hesitating . " Asleep ? "[344-sara] [she]344-sara said in a low voice .

" No , "[344-sara] said [Sara]344-sara . [She]344-sara rubbed [her]344-sara eyes . " [I]344-sara 'm awake , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara said , opening them .

[Maggie]316-maggie came across [the room]577-the room and sat down on the edge of the bed . The blind was blowing out ; the sheets were slipping off the bed . [She]316-maggie felt dazed for a moment . After [the ballroom]2125-the ballroom , [it]2158-it looked so untidy . There was a tumbler with a toothbrush in it on the wash- stand ; the towel was crumpled on the towel - horse ; and a book had fallen on the floor . [She]316-maggie stooped and picked up the book . As [she]316-maggie did so , the music burst out down [the street]587-the street . [She]316-maggie held back the blind . [The women in pale dresses]2160-the women in pale dresses , [the men in black and white]2161-the men in black and white , were crowding up the stairs into [the ballroom]2125-the ballroom . Snatches of talk and laughter were blown across [the garden]5163-the garden .

" Is there a dance ? "[316-maggie] [she]316-maggie asked .

" Yes . Down [the street]587-the street , "[344-sara] said [Sara]344-sara .

[Maggie]316-maggie looked out . At this distance the music sounded romantic , mysterious , and the colours flowed over each other , neither pink nor white nor blue .

[Maggie]316-maggie stretched [herself]316-maggie and unpinned the flower that [she]316-maggie was wearing . It was drooping ; the white petals were stained with black marks . [She]316-maggie looked out of the window again . The mixture of lights was very odd ; one leaf was a lurid green ; another was a bright white . The branches crossed each other at different levels . Then [Sally]344-sara laughed .

[She]344-sara had raised a hump of pillow against [her]344-sara head as if to shut out the dance music that was still going on . [She]344-sara pressed [her]344-sara face into a cleft of the pillows . [Maggie]316-maggie went along [the passage]738-the passage . Then [she]344-sara saw that there were lights in [the hall beneath]2209-the hall beneath . Then there was a pause . [Maggie]316-maggie could hear soda - water squirted into a tumbler ; the chink of a glass ; and then the lights went out .

1908

It was March and the wind was blowing . But it was not " blowing . "[225-eugénie] It was scraping , scourging . It was so cruel . So unbecoming . Not merely did it bleach faces and raise red spots on noses ; it tweaked up skirts ; showed stout legs ; made trousers reveal skeleton shins . There was no roundness , no fruit in it . Rather it was like the curve of a scythe which cuts , not corn , usefully ; but destroys , revelling in sheer sterility . With one blast it blew out colour - even a Rembrandt in [the National Gallery]2223-the national gallery , even a solid ruby in [a Bond Street]86-a bond street window : one blast and [they]2215-they were gone . Had it any breeding place it was in [the Isle of Dogs]2224-the isle of dogs among tin cans lying beside [a workhouse drab on [the banks of [a polluted city]2227-a polluted city]2226-the banks of a polluted city]2225-a workhouse drab on the banks of a polluted city . It tossed up rotten leaves , gave [them]2228-them another span of degraded existence ; scorned , derided [them]2228-them , yet had nothing to put in the place of [the scorned]2229-the scorned , [the derided]2230-the derided . Down [they]2215-they fell . Uncreative , unproductive , yelling its joy in destruction , its power to peel off the bark , the bloom , and show the bare bone , it paled every window ; drove [old gentlemen]2231-old gentlemen further and further into the leather smelling recesses of clubs ; and [old ladies]2232-old ladies to sit eyeless , leather cheeked , joyless among the tassels and antimacassars of [[their]2232-old ladies bedrooms and [kitchens]2234-kitchens]2233-their bedrooms and kitchens . Triumphing in its wantonness it emptied [the streets]1492-the streets ; swept flesh before [it]2236-it ; and coming smack against [a dust cart]2237-a dust cart standing outside [the Army and Navy Stores]3-the army and navy stores , scattered along the pavement a litter of old envelopes ; twists of hair ; papers already blood smeared , yellow smeared , smudged with print and sent them scudding to plaster legs , lamp posts , pillar boxes , and fold themselves frantically against area railings .

[Matty Stiles]355-matty stiles , [the caretaker]2238-the caretaker , huddled in [the basement of [the house]554-the house in [Browne Street]74-browne street]2239-the basement of the house in browne street , looked up . There was a rattle of dust along [the pavement]570-the pavement . It worked its way under the doors , through the window frames ; on to chests and dressers . But [she]2238-the caretaker did n't care . [She]2238-the caretaker was [one of [the unlucky ones]2243-the unlucky ones]2242-one of the unlucky ones . [She]2238-the caretaker had been thinking it was a safe job , sure to last the summer out anyhow . [The lady]895-the lady was dead ; [the gentleman]2245-the gentleman too . [She]2238-the caretaker had got the job through [[her]2238-the caretaker son]2246-her son [the policeman]2247-the policeman . [The house]554-the house with [[its]554-the house basement]2249-its basement would never let this side of Christmas - so [they]2250-they told [her]2238-the caretaker . [She]2238-the caretaker had only to show parties round who came with orders to view from [the agent]2251-the agent . And [she]2238-the caretaker always mentioned [the basement]521-the basement - how damp [it]521-the basement was . " Look at that stain on the ceiling . "[2238-the caretaker] There it was , sure enough . All the same , [the party from [China]87-china]2253-the party from china took a fancy to it . It suited [him]2245-the gentleman , [he]2245-the gentleman said . [He]2245-the gentleman had business in [the city]5310-the city . [She]2238-the caretaker was [one of [the unlucky ones]2243-the unlucky ones]2242-one of the unlucky ones - after three months to turn out and lodge with [[her]2238-the caretaker son]2246-her son in [Pimlico]88-pimlico .

A bell rang . Let [him]2245-the gentleman ring , ring , ring , [she]2238-the caretaker growled . [She]2238-the caretaker was n't going to open the door any more . There [he]2245-the gentleman was standing on the door - step . [She]2238-the caretaker could see a pair of legs against the railing . Let [him]2245-the gentleman ring as much as [he]2245-the gentleman liked . [The house]554-the house was sold . Could n't [he]2245-the gentleman see the notice on the board ? Could n't [he]2245-the gentleman read it ? Had n't [he]2245-the gentleman eyes ? [She]2238-the caretaker huddled closer to the fire , which was covered with pale ash . [She]2238-the caretaker could see [his]2245-the gentleman legs there , standing on the door - step , between [the canaries]2259-the canaries ' cage and the dirty linen which [she]2238-the caretaker had been going to wash , but this wind made [her]2238-the caretaker shoulder ache cruel . Let [him]2245-the gentleman ring [the house]554-the house down , for all [she]2238-the caretaker cared .

[Martin]205-martin was standing there .

" Sold "[205-martin] was written on a strip of bright red paper pasted across the house - [agent]2261-agent 's board .

" Already ! "[205-martin] said [Martin]205-martin . [He]205-martin had made a little circle to look at [the house in [Browne Street]74-browne street]2262-the house in browne street . And [it]2262-the house in browne street was already sold . The red strip gave [him]205-martin a shock . It was sold already , and [Digby]224-digby had only been dead three months - Eugénie not much more than a year . [He]205-martin stood for a moment gazing at the black windows now grimed with dust . [It]2262-the house in browne street was [a house of character]2263-a house of character ; built some time in the eighteenth century . [Eugénie]225-eugénie had been proud of [it]2262-the house in browne street . And [I]0-i used to like going [there]576-there , [he]205-martin thought . But now an old newspaper was on the door - step ; wisps of straw had caught in the railings ; and [he]205-martin could see , for there were no blinds , into [an empty room]2265-an empty room . [A woman]5302-a woman was peering up at [him]205-martin from behind the bars of a cage in [the basement]521-the basement . It was no use ringing . [He]205-martin turned away . A feeling of something extinguished came over [him]205-martin as [he]205-martin went down [the street]587-the street .

It 's a grimy , it 's a sordid end , [he]205-martin thought ; [I]0-i used to enjoy going [there]576-there . But [he]205-martin disliked brooding over unpleasant thoughts . What 's the good of it ? [he]205-martin asked [himself]205-martin .

[She]276-eleanor leant back in [her]276-eleanor chair . How terrible old age was , [she]276-eleanor thought ; shearing off all one 's faculties , one by one , but leaving something alive in the centre : leaving - [she]276-eleanor swept up the press cuttings - a game of chess , a drive in [the park]562-the park , and a visit from [old General Arbuthnot]307-arbuthnot in the evening .

It was better to die , like [Eugénie]225-eugénie and [Digby]224-digby , in the prime of life with all one 's faculties about one . But [he]205-martin was n't like that , [she]276-eleanor thought , glancing at the press cuttings . " [A man of singularly handsome presence . . . shot , fished , and played golf]5429-a man of singularly handsome presence . . . shot , fished , and played golf . "[205-martin] No , not like that in the least . [He]205-martin had been [a curious man]2302-a curious man ; weak ; sensitive ; liking titles ; liking pictures ; and often depressed , [she]276-eleanor guessed , by [[his]205-martin wife]550-his wife 's exuberance . [She]276-eleanor pushed the cuttings away and took up [her]276-eleanor book . It was odd how different [the same person]2304-the same person seemed to [two different people]2305-two different people , [she]276-eleanor thought . There was [Martin]205-martin , liking Eugénie ; and [she]276-eleanor , liking [Digby]224-digby . [She]276-eleanor began to read .

[She]276-eleanor had always wanted to know about [Christianity]357-christianity - how it began ; what it meant , originally . [God]358-god is love , [The kingdom of [Heaven]359-heaven]2306-the kingdom of heaven is within [us]2307-us , sayings like that [she]276-eleanor thought , turning over the pages , what did they mean ? The actual words were very beautiful . But who said them - when ? Then the spout of the tea - kettle puffed steam at [her]276-eleanor and [she]276-eleanor moved it away . The wind was rattling the windows in [the back room]724-the back room ; it was bending the little bushes ; they still had no leaves on them . It was what [a man]814-a man said under a fig tree , on [a hill]2310-a hill , [she]276-eleanor thought . And then [another man]544-another man wrote it down . But suppose that what [that man]1368-that man says is just as false as what [this man]5284-this man - [she]276-eleanor touched the press cuttings with [her]276-eleanor spoon - says about [Digby]224-digby ? And here am [I]0-i , [she]276-eleanor thought , looking at the china in the Dutch cabinet , in [this drawing - room]2314-this drawing - room , getting a little spark from what [someone]591-someone said all those years ago - here it comes the china was changing from blue to livid skipping over [all those mountains]2316-all those mountains , [all those seas]2317-all those seas . [She]276-eleanor found [her]276-eleanor place and began to read .

But a sound in [the hall]638-the hall interrupted [her]276-eleanor . Was [someone]591-someone coming in ? [She]276-eleanor listened . No , it was the wind . The wind was terrific . It pressed on [the house]554-the house ; gripped it tight , then let it fall apart . Upstairs a door slammed ; a window must be open in [the bedroom]737-the bedroom above . A blind was tapping . It was difficult to fix [her]276-eleanor mind on [Renan]356-renan . [She]276-eleanor liked it , though . French [she]276-eleanor could read easily of course ; and Italian ; and a little German . But what vast gaps there were , what blank spaces , [she]276-eleanor thought leaning back in [her]276-eleanor chair , in [her]276-eleanor knowledge ! How little [she]276-eleanor knew about anything . Take this cup for instance ; [she]276-eleanor held it out in front of [her]276-eleanor . What was it made of ? [Atoms]360-atoms ? And what were atoms , and how did they stick together ? The smooth hard surface of the china with its red flowers seemed to [her]276-eleanor for a second a marvellous mystery . But there was another sound in [the hall]638-the hall . It was the wind , but it was also a voice , talking . It must be [Martin]205-martin . But who could [he]205-martin be talking to , [she]276-eleanor wondered ? [She]276-eleanor listened , but [she]276-eleanor could not hear what [he]205-martin was saying because of the wind . And why , [she]276-eleanor asked [herself]276-eleanor , did [he]205-martin say [We]2323-we ca n't tell a lie to save [our]2323-we souls ? [He]205-martin was thinking about [himself]205-martin ; [one]847-one always knew when [people]503-people were thinking about [themselves]503-people by [their]503-people tone of voice . Perhaps [he]205-martin was justifying [himself]205-martin for having left [the Army]90-the army . That had been courageous , [she]276-eleanor thought ; but is n't it odd , [she]276-eleanor mused , listening to the voices , that [he]205-martin should be such [a dandy]2326-a dandy too ? [He]205-martin was wearing a new blue suit with white stripes on it . And [he]205-martin had shaved off [his]205-martin moustache . [He]205-martin ought never to have been [a soldier]2327-a soldier , [she]276-eleanor thought ; [he]205-martin was much too pugnacious . . . . [They]2328-they were still talking . [She]276-eleanor could not hear what [he]205-martin was saying , but from the sound of [his]205-martin voice it came over [her]276-eleanor that [he]205-martin must have a great many love affairs . Yes - it became perfectly obvious to [her]276-eleanor , listening to [his]205-martin voice through the door , that [he]205-martin had a great many love affairs . But who with ? and why do [men]1412-men think love affairs so important ? [she]276-eleanor asked as the door opened .

" [Hullo]333-hullo , [Rose]204-rose ! "[276-eleanor] [she]276-eleanor exclaimed , surprised to see [[her]276-eleanor sister]615-her sister come in too . " [I]276-eleanor thought [you]204-rose were in [Northumberland]91-northumberland ! "[276-eleanor]

" [You]204-rose thought [I]204-rose was in [Northumberland]91-northumberland ! "[204-rose] [Rose]204-rose laughed , kissing [her]615-her sister . " But why ? [I]204-rose said the eighteenth . "[204-rose]

" But is n't today the eleventh ? "[276-eleanor] said [Eleanor]276-eleanor .

" [You]276-eleanor 're only a week behind the times , [Nell]276-eleanor , "[205-martin] said [Martin]205-martin .

" Tea , [Rose]204-rose ? "[276-eleanor] [she]276-eleanor asked .

[Rose]204-rose threw [her]204-rose head up rather like a horse . [They]2331-they always bickered , [Eleanor]276-eleanor thought - [Martin]205-martin and [Rose]204-rose . [Rose]204-rose was handsome , but [she]204-rose wished [she]204-rose dressed better . " And the meetings ? "[276-eleanor] [Eleanor]276-eleanor asked .

[They]2334-they began to discuss politics . [She]204-rose had been speaking at a by- election . A stone had been thrown at [her]204-rose ; [she]204-rose put [her]204-rose hand to [her]204-rose chin . But [she]204-rose had enjoyed it .

[She]204-rose ought to have been [the soldier]2335-the soldier , [Eleanor]276-eleanor thought . [She]204-rose was exactly like the picture of [old Uncle Pargiter]229-pargiter of [Pargiter]229-pargiter 's Horse . Perhaps [an architect]2336-an architect , [she]276-eleanor thought . [He]205-martin 's so - [she]276-eleanor looked up . Now it was hailing . White rods came across the window in [the back room]724-the back room . There was a great gust of wind ; the little bushes blanched and bent under it . The rain must be coming in .

" [Eleanor]276-eleanor - ' said [Rose]204-rose . "[276-eleanor] [Eleanor]276-eleanor " - [she]204-rose repeated .[276-eleanor]

When did [she]204-rose do that ? [Eleanor]276-eleanor thought . [She]276-eleanor could not remember . [She]204-rose looked at the white mark . It must have bled .

" Oh , [Rose]204-rose always was [a firebrand]5439-a firebrand ! "[205-martin] said [Martin]205-martin . [He]205-martin got up . " [She]204-rose always had [the devil]5440-the devil 's own temper , "[205-martin] [he]205-martin added . [He]205-martin nodded without saying anything . [He]205-martin met [all sorts of people [she]276-eleanor did not know]2344-all sorts of people she did not know , [she]276-eleanor reflected ; and [he]205-martin did not want to talk about [them]2344-all sorts of people she did not know . [He]205-martin had turned to the fireplace .

[He]205-martin saw [her]204-rose standing with [her]204-rose back to [the school - room]2347-the school - room door ; very red in the face , with [her]204-rose lips tight shut as they were now . 1910

In [the country]501-the country it was an ordinary day enough ; one of the long reel of days that turned as the years passed from green to orange ; from grass to harvest . It was neither hot nor cold , an English spring day , bright enough , but a purple cloud behind [the hill]2350-the hill might mean rain . The grasses rippled with shadow , and then with sunlight .

In [London]1-london , however , the stricture and pressure of the season were already felt , especially in [the West End]508-the west end , where flags flew ; canes tapped ; dresses flowed ; and [houses freshly painted]2352-houses freshly painted had awnings spread and swinging baskets of red geraniums . [The Parks]2353-the parks too - [St. James 's]7-st. james , [the Green Park]561-the green park , [Hyde Park]6-hyde park - were making ready . Already in the morning before there was a chance of a procession , the green chairs were ranged among the plump brown flower beds with [their]2355-their curled hyacinths , as if waiting for something to happen ; for a curtain to rise ; for [Queen Alexandra]362-queen alexandra to come , bowing through the gates . [She]362-queen alexandra had a face like a flower petal , and always wore [her]362-queen alexandra pink carnation .

[Men]1412-men lay flat on the grass reading newspapers with [their]1412-men shirts open ; on the bald scrubbed space by the Marble Arch speakers congregated ; [nursemaids]2357-nursemaids vacantly regarded [them]1412-men ; and [mothers]2358-mothers , squatted on the grass , watched [[their]2358-mothers children]2359-their children play . Down [Park Lane]93-park lane and [Piccadilly]5-piccadilly vans , [cars , omnibuses]2360-cars , omnibuses ran along [the streets]1492-the streets as if [the streets]1492-the streets were slots ; stopped and jerked ; as if a puzzle were solved , and then broken , for it was the season , and [the streets]1492-the streets were crowded . Over [Park Lane]93-park lane and [Piccadilly]5-piccadilly the clouds kept [their]2364-their freedom , wandering fitfully , staining windows gold , daubing them black , passed and vanished , though marble in [Italy]70-italy looked no more solid , gleaming in [the quarries]2365-the quarries , veined with yellow , than the clouds over [Park Lane]93-park lane .

If [the bus]1577-the bus stopped [here]5159-here , [Rose]204-rose thought , looking down over the side , [she]204-rose would get up . [The bus]1577-the bus stopped , and [she]204-rose rose . It was a pity , [she]204-rose thought , as [she]204-rose stepped onto [the pavement]570-the pavement and caught a glimpse of [her]204-rose own figure in [a tailor]837-a tailor 's window , not to dress better , not to look nicer . Always reach - [me]0-i - downs , coats and skirts from [Whiteleys]310-whiteleys . But [they]2371-they saved time , and the years after all - [she]204-rose was over forty - made one care very little what [people]503-people thought . [They]503-people used to say , why do n't [you]2373-you marry ? Why do n't [you]2373-you do this or that , interfering . But not any longer .

[She]204-rose paused in one of the little alcoves that were scooped out in [the bridge]2062-the bridge , from habit . [People]503-people always stopped to look at [the river]813-the river . [It]813-the river was running fast , a muddy gold this morning with smooth breadths and ripples , for the tide was high . And there was the usual tug and [the usual barges with black tarpaulins]2377-the usual barges with black tarpaulins and corn showing . The water swirled round the arches . As [she]204-rose stood there , looking down at [the water]5356-the water , some buried feeling began to arrange [the stream]2379-the stream into a pattern . The pattern was painful . [She]204-rose remembered how [she]204-rose had stood [there]576-there on the night of a certain engagement , crying ; [her]204-rose tears had fallen , [her]204-rose happiness , it seemed to [her]204-rose , had fallen . Then [she]204-rose had turned - here [she]204-rose turned - and had seen [the churches]2381-the churches , the masts and roofs of [the city]5310-the city . There 's THAT , [she]204-rose had said to [herself]204-rose . Indeed it was a splendid view . . . . [She]204-rose looked , and then again [she]204-rose turned . There were [the Houses of Parliament]2383-the houses of parliament . A queer expression , half frown , half smile , formed on [her]204-rose face and [she]204-rose threw [herself]204-rose slightly backwards , as if [she]204-rose were leading [an army]2384-an army .

" [Damned humbugs]5445-damned humbugs ! "[204-rose] [she]204-rose said aloud , striking [her]204-rose fist on the balustrade . [A clerk who was passing]2385-a clerk who was passing looked at [her]204-rose with surprise . [She]204-rose laughed . [She]204-rose often talked aloud . Why not ? That too was one of the consolations , like [her]204-rose coat and skirt , and the hat [she]204-rose stuck on without giving a look in the glass . If [people]503-people chose to laugh , let [them]503-people . [She]204-rose strode on . [She]204-rose was lunching in [Hyams Place]94-hyams place with [[her]204-rose cousins]2387-her cousins . [She]204-rose had asked [herself]204-rose on the spur of the moment , meeting [Maggie]316-maggie in [a shop]2388-a shop . First [she]204-rose had heard a voice ; then seen a hand . And it was odd , considering how little [she]204-rose knew [them]2387-her cousins - [they]2387-her cousins had lived abroad - how strongly , sitting there at the counter before [Maggie]316-maggie saw [her]204-rose , simply from the sound of [her]204-rose voice , [she]204-rose had felt - [she]204-rose supposed it was affection ? - some feeling bred of blood in common . [She]204-rose had got up and said May [I]0-i come and see [you]316-maggie ? busy as [she]204-rose was , hating to break [her]204-rose day in the middle . [She]204-rose walked on . [They]2387-her cousins lived in [Hyams Place]94-hyams place , over [the river]813-the river - [Hyams Place]94-hyams place , [that little crescent of old houses with the name carved in the middle which [she]204-rose used to pass so often when [she]204-rose lived down [here]5159-here]2390-that little crescent of old houses with the name carved in the middle which she used to pass so often when she lived down here . [She]204-rose used to ask [herself]204-rose in those far - off days Who was [Hyam]363-hyam ? But [she]204-rose had never solved the question to [her]204-rose satisfaction . [She]204-rose walked on , across [the river]813-the river .

[The shabby street on [the south side of [the river]813-the river]2394-the south side of the river]2393-the shabby street on the south side of the river was very noisy . Now and again a voice detached itself from the general clamour . [A woman]5302-a woman shouted to [[her]5302-a woman neighbour]2397-her neighbour ; [a child]1713-a child cried . [A man trundling a barrow]2399-a man trundling a barrow opened [his]2399-a man trundling a barrow mouth and bawled up at the windows as [he]2399-a man trundling a barrow passed . There were bedsteads , grates , pokers and odd pieces of twisted iron on [his]2399-a man trundling a barrow barrow . But whether [he]2399-a man trundling a barrow was selling old iron or buying old iron it was impossible to say ; the rhythm persisted ; but the words were almost rubbed out .

The swarm of sound , the rush of traffic , the shouts of [the hawkers , the single cries and the general cries]2400-the hawkers , the single cries and the general cries , came into [the upper room of [the house in [Hyams]95-hyams Place where [Sara Pargiter]344-sara]2402-the house in hyams place where sara pargiter sat at the piano]2401-the upper room of the house in hyams place where sara pargiter sat at the piano . [She]204-rose was singing . Then [she]204-rose stopped ; [she]204-rose watched [[her]204-rose sister]615-her sister laying the table .

" Go search [the valleys]2118-the valleys , "[204-rose] [she]204-rose murmured , as [she]204-rose watched [her]615-her sister , " pluck up every rose . "[204-rose] [She]204-rose paused . " That 's very nice , "[204-rose] [she]204-rose added , dreamily . [Maggie]316-maggie had taken a bunch of flowers ; had cut the tight little string which bound them , and had laid them side by side on the table ; and was arranging them in an earthenware pot . They were differently coloured , blue , white and purple . [Sara]344-sara watched [her]316-maggie arranging them . [She]344-sara laughed suddenly .

" What are [you]344-sara laughing at ? "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie absent - mindedly . [She]316-maggie added a purple flower to the bunch and looked at it .

" Dazed in a rapture of contemplation , "[344-sara] said [Sara]344-sara , ' shading [her]344-sara eyes with peacocks ' feathers dipped in morning dew - " [she]344-sara pointed to the table . "[316-maggie] [Maggie]316-maggie said , " [she]316-maggie jumped up and pirouetted about [the room]577-the room , "[316-maggie] three 's the same as two , three 's the same as two . " [She]316-maggie pointed to the table upon which three places had been laid .[316-maggie]

" But [we]5448-we are three , "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie . " [Rose]204-rose is coming . "[316-maggie] [Sara]344-sara stopped . [Her]344-sara face fell .

" [Rose]204-rose is coming ? "[344-sara] [she]344-sara repeated .

" [I]316-maggie told [you]344-sara , "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie . " [I]344-sara said to [you]344-sara , [Rose]204-rose is coming to luncheon on Friday . It is Friday . And [Rose]204-rose is coming to luncheon . Any minute now , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara said . [She]344-sara got up and began to fold some stuff that was lying on the floor .

" It is Friday , and [Rose]204-rose is coming to luncheon , "[344-sara] [Sara]344-sara repeated .

" [I]316-maggie told [you]344-sara , "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie . " [I]344-sara was in [a shop]2388-a shop . [I]344-sara was buying stuff . And [somebody]579-somebody "[344-sara] - [she]344-sara paused to make [her]344-sara fold more accurately - " came out from behind a counter and said , ' [I]344-sara 'm [[your]344-sara cousin]5451-your cousin . [I]344-sara 'm [Rose]204-rose , ' [she]344-sara said . ' Can [I]344-sara come and see [you]344-sara ? Any day , any time , ' [she]344-sara said . So [I]344-sara said , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara put the stuff on a chair , " lunch . "[344-sara]

[She]344-sara looked round [the room]577-the room to see that everything was in readiness . Chairs were missing . [Sara]344-sara pulled up a chair .

" [Rose]204-rose is coming , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara said , " and this is where [she]204-rose 'll sit . "[344-sara] [She]344-sara placed the chair at the table facing the window . " And [she]204-rose 'll take off [her]204-rose gloves ; and [she]204-rose 'll lay one on this side , one on that . And [she]204-rose 'll say , [I]344-sara 've never been in [this part of [London]1-london]5452-this part of london before . ' "[344-sara]

" And then ? "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie , looking at the table .

" [You]344-sara 'll say ' It 's so convenient for [the theatres]1027-the theatres . ' "[344-sara]

" And then ? "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie .

" And then [she]204-rose 'll say rather wistfully , smiling , putting [her]204-rose head on one side , ' D'you often go to [the theatre]5454-the theatre , [Maggie]316-maggie ? ' "[344-sara]

" No , "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie . " [Rose]204-rose has red hair . "[316-maggie]

" Red hair ? "[344-sara] [Sara]344-sara exclaimed . " [I]344-sara thought it was grey - a little wisp straggling from under a black bonnet , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara added .

" No , "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie . " [She]204-rose has a great deal of hair ; and it 's red . "[316-maggie]

" Red hair ; red Rose , "[344-sara] [Sara]344-sara exclaimed . [She]344-sara spun round on [her]344-sara toe .

" Rose of the flaming heart ; Rose of the burning breast ; Rose of the weary world - red , red Rose ! "[316-maggie]

A door slammed below ; [they]2405-they heard footsteps mounting the stairs . " There [she]204-rose is , "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie .

The steps stopped . [They]2405-they heard a voice saying , " Still further up ? On the very top ? Thank [you]344-sara . "[2405-they] Then the steps began mounting the stairs again .

" This is the worst torture . . . "[344-sara] [Sara]344-sara began , screwing [her]344-sara hands together and clinging to [[her]344-sara sister]615-her sister , " that life . . . . "[344-sara]

" Do n't be such an ass , "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie , pushing [her]615-her sister away , as the door opened .

[Rose]204-rose came in .

" It 's ages since [we]2405-they met , "[204-rose] [she]204-rose said , shaking hands .

[She]204-rose wondered what had made [her]204-rose come . Everything was different from what [she]204-rose expected . [The room]577-the room was rather poverty - stricken ; the carpet did not cover the floor . There was a sewing - machine in the corner , and [Maggie]316-maggie too looked different from what [she]316-maggie had looked in [the shop]1641-the shop . But there was a crimson - and - gilt chair ; [she]204-rose recognised it with relief .

" That used to stand in [the hall]638-the hall , did n't it ? "[204-rose] [she]204-rose said , putting [her]204-rose bag down on the chair .

There was a pause . There seemed to be nothing to say .

[The man]826-the man was crying under the window . [She]316-maggie looked out of the window . "[204-rose]

" [He]346-uncle abel 's still alive , "[204-rose] said [Rose]204-rose .

[She]204-rose was [a little girl wearing a pink frock]2422-a little girl wearing a pink frock ; and here [she]204-rose was in [this room]843-this room , now . It was very quiet . The noise of the traffic had ceased . The trees were not in full leaf yet , and pigeons were shuffling and crooning on the tree tops . [[Covent Garden]79-covent garden porters]2531-covent garden porters , [dingy little clerks in [their]2532-dingy little clerks in their ordinary working clothes ordinary working clothes]2532-dingy little clerks in their ordinary working clothes , [coarse - looking women in aprons]2533-coarse - looking women in aprons stared in at [her]254-kitty . The air smelt strongly of oranges and bananas . But [the car]2512-the car was coming to a standstill . It drew up under the archway ; [she]254-kitty pushed through the glass doors and went in .

[She]254-kitty felt at once a sense of relief . Now that the daylight was extinguished and the air glowed yellow and crimson , [she]254-kitty no longer felt absurd . On the contrary , [she]254-kitty felt appropriate . The ladies and [gentlemen who were mounting the stairs]2535-gentlemen who were mounting the stairs were dressed exactly as [she]254-kitty was . The smell of oranges and bananas had been replaced by another smell - a subtle mixture of clothes and gloves and flowers that affected [her]254-kitty pleasantly . The carpet was thick beneath [her]254-kitty feet . [She]254-kitty went along [the corridor]2536-the corridor till [she]254-kitty came to [her]254-kitty own box with the card on it . [She]254-kitty went in and [the whole Opera House]2537-the whole opera house opened in front of [her]254-kitty . [She]254-kitty was not late after all . [The orchestra]2538-the orchestra was still tuning up ; [the players]2539-the players were laughing , talking and turning round in [their]2539-the players seats as [they]2539-the players fiddled busily with [their]2539-the players instruments . [She]254-kitty stood looking down at [the stalls]2540-the stalls . The floor of [the house]554-the house was in a state of great agitation . [People]503-people were passing to [their]503-people seats ; [they]503-people were sitting down and getting up again ; [they]503-people were taking off [their]503-people cloaks and signalling to [friends]586-friends . [They]503-people were like birds settling on [a field]958-a field . In the boxes white figures were appearing here and there ; white arms rested on the ledges of boxes ; white shirt - fronts shone beside [them]503-people . [The whole house]2545-the whole house glowed - red , gold , cream - coloured , and smelt of clothes and flowers , and echoed with the squeaks and trills of the instruments and with the buzz and hum of voices . [She]254-kitty glanced at the programme that was laid on the ledge of [her]254-kitty box . It was [Siegfried]373-siegfried - [[her]254-kitty favourite opera]2546-her favourite opera . [She]254-kitty stooped to read them ; then a thought struck [her]254-kitty and [she]254-kitty glanced at the royal box . It was empty . " [They]2548-two men have n't put it off ? "[1135-her husband] [he]1135-her husband said as [he]1135-her husband shook hands . " [I]1135-her husband was afraid [they]2548-two men might . "[1135-her husband] [He]1135-her husband was something in [the Foreign Office]2554-the foreign office ; with a handsome Roman head .

[They]2555-they all looked instinctively at the royal box . [Programmes]374-programmes lay along the edge ; but there was no bouquet of pink carnations . [The box]2556-the box was empty .

" [The doctors]5516-the doctors have given [him]713-the young man up , "[713-the young man] said [the young man]713-the young man , looking very important . [They]2555-they all think [they]2555-they know everything , [Kitty]254-kitty thought , smiling at [his]713-the young man air of private information .

" But if [he]713-the young man dies ? "[254-kitty] [she]254-kitty said , looking at the royal box , " d'you think [they]5516-the doctors 'll stop it ? "[254-kitty]

[The young man]713-the young man shrugged [his]713-the young man shoulders . About that [he]713-the young man could not be positive apparently . [The house]554-the house was filling up . Lights winked on [ladies]1142-ladies ' arms as [they]1142-ladies turned ; ripples of light flashed , stopped , and then flashed the opposite way as [they]1142-ladies turned [their]1142-ladies heads .

But now [the conductor]1668-the conductor pushed [his]1668-the conductor way through [the orchestra]2538-the orchestra to [his]1668-the conductor raised seat . There was an outburst of applause ; [he]1668-the conductor turned , bowed to [the audience]2563-the audience ; turned again , all the lights sank down ; the overture had begun .

[Kitty]254-kitty leant back against the wall of the box ; [her]254-kitty face was shaded by the folds of the curtain . [She]254-kitty was glad to be shaded . As [they]2564-they played the overture [she]254-kitty looked at [Edward]369-edward . [She]254-kitty could only see the outline of [his]369-edward face in the red glow ; it was heavier than it used to be ; but [he]369-edward looked intellectual , handsome and a little remote as [he]369-edward listened to the overture . It would n't have done , [she]254-kitty thought ; [I]0-i 'm much too . . . [she]254-kitty did not finish the sentence . [He]369-edward has never married , [she]254-kitty thought ; and [she]254-kitty had . And [I]0-i 've [three boys]2565-three boys . [I]0-i 've been in [Australia]106-australia , [I]0-i 've been in [India]13-india . . . . The music made [her]254-kitty think of [herself]254-kitty and [her]254-kitty own life as [she]254-kitty seldom did . It exalted [her]254-kitty ; it cast a flattering light over [herself]254-kitty , [her]254-kitty past . But why did [Martin]205-martin laugh at [me]0-i for having [a car]2494-a car ? [she]254-kitty thought . What 's the good of laughing ? [she]254-kitty asked .

Here the curtain went up . [She]254-kitty leant forward and looked at [the stage]2567-the stage . [The dwarf]2568-the dwarf was hammering at the sword . [Hammer]277-hammer , hammer , hammer , [he]2568-the dwarf went with little short , sharp strokes . [She]254-kitty listened . The music had changed . [HE]2568-the dwarf , [she]254-kitty thought , looking at [the handsome boy]2569-the handsome boy , knows exactly what the music means . [He]2568-the dwarf was already completely possessed by the music . [She]254-kitty liked the look of complete absorption that had swum up on top of [his]2568-the dwarf immaculate respectability , making [him]2568-the dwarf seem almost stern . . . . But here was [Siegfried]373-siegfried . [She]254-kitty leant forward . Dressed in leopard - skins , very fat , with nut - brown thighs , leading a bear - here [he]373-siegfried was . [She]254-kitty liked [the fat bouncing young man in [his]373-siegfried flaxen wig]2570-the fat bouncing young man in his flaxen wig : [his]373-siegfried voice was magnificent . [Hammer]277-hammer , hammer , hammer [he]373-siegfried went . [She]254-kitty leant back again . What did that make [her]254-kitty think of ? [A young man who came into [a room]2572-a room with shavings in [his]373-siegfried hair . . . when [she]254-kitty was very young . Or was it the farm hand up at [[Carter]240-carter 's]2577-carter 's , when [old Carter]240-carter had loomed up suddenly leading a bull with a ring through its nose ?

" That 's the sort of life [I]254-kitty like , "[254-kitty] [she]254-kitty thought , taking up [her]254-kitty opera- glasses . " That 's the sort of person [I]254-kitty am . . . . "[254-kitty] [she]254-kitty finished [her]254-kitty sentence .

Then [she]254-kitty put the opera - glasses to [her]254-kitty eyes . The scenery suddenly became bright and close ; the grass seemed to be made of thick green wool ; [she]254-kitty could see [Siegfried]373-siegfried 's fat brown arms glistening with paint . [His]373-siegfried face was shiny . [She]254-kitty put down the glasses and leant back in [her]254-kitty corner .

And old [Lucy Craddock]269-lucy - [she]254-kitty saw [Lucy]269-lucy sitting at a table ; with [her]269-lucy red nose , and [her]269-lucy patient , kind eyes . " So [you]254-kitty 've done no work this week again , [Kitty]254-kitty ! "[254-kitty] [she]254-kitty said reproachfully . How [I]0-i loved [her]269-lucy ! [Kitty]254-kitty thought . And then [she]254-kitty had gone back to [the Lodge]1087-the lodge ; and there was the tree , with a prop in the middle ; and [[her]254-kitty mother]685-her mother sitting bolt upright . . . . [I]0-i wish [I]0-i had n't quarrelled so much with [[my]0-i mother]5248-my mother , [she]254-kitty thought , overcome with a sudden sense of the passage of time and its tragedy . Then the music changed .

[She]254-kitty looked at the stage again . [The Wanderer]2581-the wanderer had come in . [He]2581-the wanderer was sitting on a bank in a long grey dressing - gown ; and a patch wobbled uncomfortably over one of [his]2581-the wanderer eyes . On and on [he]2581-the wanderer went ; on and on . [Her]254-kitty attention flagged . [She]254-kitty glanced round [the dim red house]2582-the dim red house ; [she]254-kitty could only see white elbows pointed on the ledges of boxes ; here and there a sharp pinpoint of light showed as [some one]2583-some one followed the score with a torch . [Edward]369-edward 's fine profile again caught [her]254-kitty eye . [He]369-edward was listening , critically , intently . It would n't have done , [she]254-kitty thought , it would n't have done at all .

At last [the Wanderer]2581-the wanderer had gone . And now ? [she]254-kitty asked [herself]254-kitty , leaning forward . [Siegfried]373-siegfried burst in . Dressed in [his]373-siegfried leopard - skins , laughing and singing , here [he]373-siegfried was again . The music excited [her]254-kitty . It was magnificent . [Siegfried]373-siegfried took the broken pieces of the sword and blew on the fire and hammered , hammered , hammered . The singing , the hammering and the fire leaping all went on at the same time . Quicker and quicker , more and more rhythmically , more and more triumphantly [he]373-siegfried hammered , until at last up [he]373-siegfried swung the sword high above [his]373-siegfried head and brought it down - crack ! The anvil burst asunder . And then [he]373-siegfried brandished the sword over [his]373-siegfried head and shouted and sang ; and the music rushed higher and higher ; and the curtain fell .

The lights opened in the middle of [the house]554-the house . All the colour came back . [The whole Opera House]2537-the whole opera house leapt into life again with [its]2537-the whole opera house faces and [its]2537-the whole opera house diamonds and [its men]2587-its men and [women]1429-women . [They]2589-they were clapping and waving [their]2589-they programmes . [The whole house]2545-the whole house seemed to be fluttering with white squares of paper . The curtains fell apart and were held back by [tall footmen in knee - breeches]2591-tall footmen in knee - breeches . [Kitty]254-kitty stood up and clapped . Again the curtains closed ; again [they]2592-they parted . [The footmen]2593-the footmen were almost pulled off [their]2593-the footmen feet by the heavy folds that [they]2593-the footmen had to hold back . Again and again [they]2593-the footmen held the curtain back ; and even when [they]2593-the footmen had let it fall and [the singers]2594-the singers had disappeared and [the orchestra]2538-the orchestra were leaving [their]2538-the orchestra seats , [the audience]2563-the audience still stood clapping and waving [their]2563-the audience programmes .

[Kitty]254-kitty turned to [the young man in [her]254-kitty box]2597-the young man in her box . [He]2597-the young man in her box was leaning over the ledge . " Brandishing , flourishing [my]344-sara sword in [my]344-sara hand . . . "[344-sara] [she]344-sara sang . The words were the words of some pompous eighteenth century march , but [her]344-sara voice was reedy and thin . [Her]344-sara voice broke . [She]344-sara stopped singing .
