" Another row ? "[316-maggie] [Maggie]316-maggie murmured , sticking [her]316-maggie needle in the stuff .

[Sara]344-sara got up and went to the window . [A crowd]2614-a crowd had gathered outside [the public house]1039-the public house . [A man]814-a man was being thrown out . There [he]814-a man came , staggering . [He]814-a man fell against a lamp - post to which [he]814-a man clung . The scene was lit up by the glare of the lamp over [the public house]1039-the public house door . [Sara]344-sara stood for a moment at the window watching [them]2618-them . Then [she]344-sara turned ; [her]344-sara face in the mixed light looked cadaverous and worn , as if [she]344-sara were no longer [a girl]1090-a girl , but [an old woman worn out by a life of childbirth , debauchery and crime]2620-an old woman worn out by a life of childbirth , debauchery and crime . [She]344-sara stood there hunched up , with [her]344-sara hands clenched together .

" In time to come , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara said , looking at [[her]344-sara sister]615-her sister , " [people]503-people , looking into [this room]843-this room - [this cave]5540-this cave , this little antre , scooped out of mud and dung , will hold [their]503-people fingers to [their]503-people noses "[344-sara] - [she]344-sara held [her]344-sara fingers to [her]344-sara nose - " and say ' Pah ! [They]503-people stink ! ' "[344-sara] [She]344-sara fell down into a chair .

[Maggie]316-maggie looked at [her]344-sara . Curled round , with [her]344-sara hair falling over [her]344-sara face and [her]344-sara hands screwed together [she]344-sara looked like some great ape , crouching there in [a little cave of mud and dung]2622-a little cave of mud and dung . " Pah ! "[316-maggie] [Maggie]316-maggie repeated to [herself]316-maggie , " [They]2623-they stink "[316-maggie] . . . [She]316-maggie drove [her]316-maggie needle through the stuff in a spasm of disgust . It was true , [she]316-maggie thought ; [they]2623-they were nasty little creatures , driven by uncontrollable lusts . The night was full of roaring and cursing ; of violence and unrest , also of beauty and joy . [She]316-maggie got up , holding the dress in [her]316-maggie hands . The folds of silk fell down to the floor and [she]316-maggie ran [her]316-maggie hand over them .

" That 's done . That 's finished , "[316-maggie] [she]316-maggie said , laying the dress on the table . There was nothing more [she]316-maggie could do with [her]316-maggie hands . [She]316-maggie folded the dress up and put it away . Then the cat , which had been asleep , rose very slowly , arched its back and stretched itself to its full length .

" [You]344-sara want [your]344-sara supper , do [you]344-sara ? "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie . [She]316-maggie went into [the kitchen]620-the kitchen and came back with a saucer of milk . " There , [poor puss]5541-poor puss , "[316-maggie] [she]316-maggie said , putting the saucer down on the floor . [She]316-maggie stood watching the cat lap up its milk , mouthful by mouthful ; then it stretched itself out again with extraordinary grace .

[Sara]344-sara , standing at a little distance , watched [her]316-maggie . Then [she]344-sara imitated [her]316-maggie .

" There , [poor puss]5541-poor puss , there , [poor puss]5541-poor puss , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara repeated . " As [you]316-maggie rock the cradle , [Maggie]316-maggie , "[344-sara] [she]344-sara added .

[Maggie]316-maggie raised [her]316-maggie arms as if to ward off some implacable destiny ; then let them fall . [Sara]344-sara smiled as [she]344-sara watched [her]316-maggie ; then tears brimmed , fell and ran slowly down [her]344-sara cheeks . But as [she]316-maggie put up [her]316-maggie hand to wipe [them]2625-them there was a sound of knocking ; [somebody]579-somebody was hammering on the door of [the next house]2627-the next house . The hammering stopped . Then it began again - hammer , hammer , hammer .

[They]2628-they listened .

" [Upcher]375-upcher 's come [home]608-home drunk and wants to be let in , "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie . The knocking ceased . Then it began again .

[Sara]344-sara dried [her]344-sara eyes , roughly , energetically .

" Bring up [[your]316-maggie children]5545-your children on [a desert island]5546-a desert island where [the ships]1375-the ships only come when the moon 's full ! "[344-sara] [she]344-sara exclaimed .

" Or have none ? "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie . A window was thrown open . [A woman]5302-a woman 's voice was heard shrieking abuse at [the man]826-the man . [He]826-the man bawled back in a thick drunken voice from [the doorstep]2021-the doorstep . Then the door slammed .

[They]2628-they listened .

" Now [he]826-the man 'll stagger against the wall and be sick , "[316-maggie] said [Maggie]316-maggie . [They]2628-they could hear heavy footsteps lurching up the stairs in [the next house]2627-the next house . Then there was silence .

[Maggie]316-maggie crossed [the room]577-the room to shut the window . The great windows of [the factory opposite]2634-the factory opposite were all lit up ; [it]2635-it looked like a palace of glass with thin black bars across it . A glaze of yellow light lit up the lower halves of [the houses opposite]1417-the houses opposite ; the slate roofs shone blue , for the sky hung down in a heavy canopy of yellow light . Footsteps tapped on [the pavement]570-the pavement , for [people]503-people were still walking in [the street]587-the street . Far off a voice was crying hoarsely . [Maggie]316-maggie leant out . The night was windy and warm .

" What 's [he]2640-a man who was wheeling a barrow along the street crying ? "[316-maggie] [she]316-maggie said .

The voice came nearer and nearer .

" Death . . . ? "[316-maggie] [she]316-maggie said .

" Death . . . ? "[344-sara] said [Sara]344-sara . [They]2628-they leant out . But [they]2628-they could not hear the rest of the sentence . Then [a man who was wheeling a barrow along [the street]587-the street]2640-a man who was wheeling a barrow along the street shouted up to [them]2628-they :

" [The King]5548-the king 's dead ! "[2640-a man who was wheeling a barrow along the street]

1911

The sun was rising . Very slowly it came up over the horizon shaking out light . But the sky was so vast , so cloudless , that to fill it with light took time . Very gradually the clouds turned blue ; leaves on [forest trees]2642-forest trees sparkled ; down below a flower shone ; eyes of beasts - tigers , monkeys , birds - sparkled . Slowly [the world]5285-the world emerged from darkness . [The sea]1514-the sea became like the skin of an innumerable scaled fish , glittering gold . [Here in [the South of]2646-the south of [France]107-france [the furrowed vineyards]2647-the furrowed vineyards]2645-here in the south of france the furrowed vineyards caught the light ; the little vines turned purple and yellow ; and the sun coming through the slats of the blinds striped the white walls . [Maggie]316-maggie , standing at the window , looked down on [the courtyard]2648-the courtyard , and saw [[her]316-maggie husband]1135-her husband 's book cracked across with shadow from the vine above ; and the glass that stood beside [him]1135-her husband glowed yellow . Cries of [peasants working]2650-peasants working came through the open window .

The sun , crossing [the Channel]1496-the channel , beat vainly on the blanket of thick sea mist . Light slowly permeated the haze over [London]1-london ; struck on the statues in [Parliament Square]50-parliament square , and on [the Palace]2652-the palace where the flag flew though [the King , borne under a white and blue Union Jack]2653-the king , borne under a white and blue union jack , lay in [the caverns at [Frogmore]108-frogmore]2654-the caverns at frogmore . It was hotter than ever . [Horses]2655-horses ' noses hissed as [they]2655-horses drank from the troughs ; [their]2655-horses hoofs made ridges hard and brittle as plaster on [the country roads]2656-the country roads . Fires tearing over [the moors]5250-the moors left charcoal twigs behind [them]2658-them . It was August , the holiday season . The glass roofs of [the great railway stations]2659-the great railway stations were globes incandescent with light . [Travellers]2660-travellers watched the hands of the round yellow clocks as [they]2660-travellers followed [porters]2661-porters , wheeling portmanteaus , with dogs on leashes . In all [the stations trains]2662-the stations trains were ready to bore [their]2662-the stations trains way through [England]35-england ; to [the North]383-north , to [the South]109-the south , to [the West]110-the west . Now the guard standing with [his]2663-his hand raised dropped [his]2663-his flag and the tea - urn slid past . Off [the trains]2664-the trains swung through [the public gardens]2665-the public gardens with [asphalt paths]2666-asphalt paths ; past [the factories]2667-the factories ; into [open country]1312-open country . [Men standing on bridges fishing]2669-men standing on bridges fishing looked up ; horses cantered ; [women]1429-women came to doors and shaded [their]1429-women eyes ; the shadow of the smoke floated over the corn , looped down and caught a tree . And on [they]2664-the trains passed .

In [the station yard]2671-the station yard at [Wittering]111-wittering , [[Mrs Chinnery]376-mrs chinnery 's old victoria]2672-mrs chinnery 's old victoria stood waiting . [The train]2673-the train was late ; it was very hot . [William]377-sir william [the gardener]2674-the gardener sat on the box in [his]377-sir william buff - coloured coat with the plated buttons flicking the flies off . The flies were troublesome . [They]2675-they had gathered in little brown clusters on the horses ' ears . [He]377-sir william flicked [his]377-sir william whip ; [the old mare]2676-the old mare stamped [her]2676-the old mare hoofs ; and shook [her]2676-the old mare ears , for the flies had settled again . It was very hot . The sun beat down on [the station yard]2671-the station yard , on [the carts]1667-the carts and flies and traps waiting for [the train]2673-the train . At last the signal dropped ; a puff of smoke blew over the hedge ; and in a minute [people]503-people came streaming out into [the yard]2681-the yard , and here was [Miss Pargiter]344-sara carrying [her]344-sara bag in [her]344-sara hand and a white umbrella . [William]377-sir william touched [his]377-sir william hat .

" Sorry to be so late , "[276-eleanor] said [Eleanor]276-eleanor , smiling up at [him]377-sir william , for [she]276-eleanor knew [him]377-sir william ; [she]276-eleanor came every year .

[She]276-eleanor put [her]276-eleanor bag on the seat and sat back under the shade of [her]276-eleanor white umbrella . The leather of [the carriage]2682-the carriage was hot behind [her]276-eleanor back ; it was very hot - hotter even than [Toledo]378-toledo . [They]2683-they turned into [the High Street]112-the high street ; the heat seemed to make everything drowsy and silent . [The broad street]2684-the broad street was full of traps and carts with the reins hanging loose and the horses ' heads drooping . But after the din of [the foreign market]2685-the foreign market - places how quiet it seemed ! [Men in gaiters]2686-men in gaiters were leaning against the walls ; [the shops]1428-the shops had [their]1428-the shops awnings out ; [the pavement]570-the pavement was barred with shadow . [They]2683-they had parcels to fetch . At [the fishmonger 's]2689-the fishmonger 's [they]2683-they stopped ; and a damp white parcel was handed out to [them]2683-they . At [the ironmonger]2690-the ironmonger 's [they]2683-they stopped ; and [William]377-sir william came back with a scythe . Then [they]2683-they stopped at [the chemist 's]2691-the chemist 's ; but there [they]2683-they had to wait , because the lotion was not yet ready .

[Eleanor]276-eleanor sat back under the shade of [her]276-eleanor white umbrella . The air seemed to hum with the heat . The air seemed to smell of soap and chemicals . How thoroughly [people]503-people wash in [England]35-england , [she]276-eleanor thought , looking at the yellow soap , the green soap , and the pink soap in [the chemist]2693-the chemist 's window . In [Spain]89-spain [she]276-eleanor had hardly washed at all ; [she]276-eleanor had dried [herself]276-eleanor with a pocket handkerchief standing among the white dry stones of [the Guadalquivir]113-the guadalquivir . In [Spain]89-spain [it]2694-it was all parched and shrivelled . But here - [she]276-eleanor looked down [the High Street]112-the high street - [every shop]2695-every shop was full of vegetables ; of shining silver fish ; of yellow- clawed , soft - breasted chickens ; of buckets , rakes and wheel- barrows . And how friendly [people]503-people were !

[She]276-eleanor noticed how often hats were touched ; hands were grasped ; [people]503-people stopped , talking , in the middle of [the road]705-the road . But now [the chemist]2693-the chemist came out with a large bottle wrapped in tissue paper . It was stowed away under the scythe .

" Midges very bad this year , [William]377-sir william ? "[276-eleanor] [she]276-eleanor asked , recognising the lotion .

" Tarrible bad , [miss]5414-miss , tarrible , "[2693-the chemist] [he]2693-the chemist said , touching [his]2693-the chemist hat . [The road]705-the road was laid with soft white dust ; the hedges , hung with wreaths of [travellers]2660-travellers ' joy , seemed also thick with dust . The old horse settled down into [his]2693-the chemist mechanical jog - trot , and [Eleanor]276-eleanor lay back under [her]276-eleanor white umbrella .

Every summer [she]276-eleanor came to visit [Morris]237-morris at [[his]237-morris mother]881-his mother - in - [law 's house]2711-law 's house . Seven times , eight times [she]276-eleanor had come [she]276-eleanor counted ; but this year it was different . This year everything was different . [[Her]276-eleanor father]643-her father was dead ; [[her]276-eleanor house]2713-her house was shut up ; [she]276-eleanor had no attachment at the moment anywhere . [North]383-north read a book ; [Peggy]316-maggie strummed on the piano ; and [Celia]334-celia , dozing over [her]334-celia embroidery , now and then gave a sudden start and put [her]334-celia hand over [her]334-celia mouth . At last the door opened stealthily . [Ellen]276-eleanor , [the discreet black maid]2882-the discreet black maid stood behind [Mrs Chinnery]376-mrs chinnery 's chair , waiting . [Mrs Chinnery]376-mrs chinnery pretended to ignore [her]276-eleanor , but [the others]535-the others were glad to stop . [Ellen]276-eleanor stepped forward and [Mrs Chinnery]376-mrs chinnery , submitting , was wheeled off to [the mysterious upper chamber of extreme old age]2884-the mysterious upper chamber of extreme old age . [Her]276-eleanor pleasure was over .

[Celia]334-celia yawned openly .

" [The bazaar]5590-the bazaar , "[334-celia] [she]334-celia said , rolling up [her]334-celia embroidery . " [I]334-celia shall go to bed . Come , [Peggy]316-maggie . Come , [Eleanor]276-eleanor . "[334-celia]

[North]383-north jumped up with alacrity to open the door . [Celia]334-celia lit the brass candlesticks and began , rather heavily , to climb the stairs . [Eleanor]276-eleanor followed after . But [Peggy]316-maggie lagged behind . [Eleanor]276-eleanor heard [her]316-maggie whispering with [[her]316-maggie brother]1106-her brother in [the hall]638-the hall .

" Come along , [Peggy]316-maggie , "[334-celia] [Celia]334-celia called back over the banister as [she]334-celia toiled [upstairs]684-upstairs . When [she]334-celia got to [the landing at the top]2888-the landing at the top [she]334-celia stopped under the picture of [the little Chinnerys]390-the chinnerys and called back again rather sharply :

" Come , [Peggy]316-maggie . "[334-celia] There was a pause . Then [Peggy]316-maggie came , reluctantly . [She]316-maggie kissed [[her]316-maggie mother]685-her mother obediently ; but [she]316-maggie did not look in the least sleepy . [She]316-maggie looked extremely pretty and rather flushed . [She]316-maggie did not mean to go to bed , [Eleanor]276-eleanor felt sure .

[She]316-maggie went into [[her]316-maggie room]2890-her room and undressed . All the windows were open and [she]316-maggie heard the trees rustling in [the garden]5163-the garden . It was so hot still that [she]316-maggie lay in [her]316-maggie nightgown on top of the bed with only the sheet over [her]316-maggie . The candle burnt its little pear - shaped flame on the table by [her]316-maggie side . [She]316-maggie lay listening vaguely to the trees in [the garden]5163-the garden ; and watched the shadow of a moth that dashed round and round [the room]577-the room . Either [I]0-i must get up and shut the window or blow out the candle , [she]316-maggie thought drowsily . [She]316-maggie did not want to do either . [She]316-maggie wanted to lie still . It was a relief to lie in the semi - darkness after the talk , after the cards . [She]316-maggie could still see the cards falling ; black , red and yellow ; [kings]1199-kings , [queens]2895-queens and [knaves]2896-knaves ; on a green baize table . [She]316-maggie looked drowsily round [her]316-maggie . A nice vase of flowers stood on the dressing - table ; there was the polished wardrobe and a china box by [her]316-maggie bedside . [She]316-maggie lifted the lid . Yes ; four biscuits and a pale piece of chocolate - in case [she]316-maggie should be hungry in the night . [Celia]334-celia had provided books too , The Diary of [a Nobody]2897-a nobody , [Ruff]391-ruff 's Tour in [Northumberland]91-northumberland and an odd volume of Dante , in case [she]334-celia should wish to read in the night . [She]316-maggie took one of the books and laid it on the counterpane beside [her]316-maggie . Perhaps because [she]316-maggie had been travelling , it seemed as if [the ship]2898-the ship were still padding softly through [the sea]1514-the sea ; as if [the train]2673-the train were still swinging from side to side as [it]2673-the train rattled across [France]107-france . [She]316-maggie felt as if things were moving past [her]316-maggie as [she]316-maggie lay stretched on the bed under the single sheet . But it 's not the landscape any longer , [she]316-maggie thought ; it 's [people]503-people 's lives , [their]503-people changing lives .

The door of [the pink bedroom]2902-the pink bedroom shut . [William Whatney]377-sir william coughed next door . [She]316-maggie heard [him]377-sir william cross [the room]577-the room . Now [he]377-sir william was standing by the window , smoking a last cigar . What 's [he]377-sir william thinking , [she]316-maggie wondered - about [India]13-india ? - how [he]377-sir william stood under a peacock umbrella ? Then [he]377-sir william began moving about [the room]577-the room , undressing . [She]316-maggie could hear [him]377-sir william take up a brush and put it down again on [his]377-sir william dressing - table . And it 's to [him]377-sir william , [she]316-maggie thought , remembering the wide sweep of [his]377-sir william chin and the floating stains of pink and yellow that lay underneath it , that [I]0-i owe that moment , which had been more than pleasure , when [she]316-maggie hid [her]316-maggie face behind the newspaper in the corner of [the third - class railway carriage]2905-the third - class railway carriage .

Now there were three moths dashing round the ceiling . [They]2906-they made a little tapping noise as they dashed round and round from corner to corner . If [she]316-maggie left the window open much longer [the room]577-the room would be full of moths . A board creaked in the passage outside . [She]316-maggie listened . [Peggy]316-maggie , was it , escaping , to join [[her]316-maggie brother]1106-her brother ? [She]316-maggie felt sure there was some scheme on foot . But [she]316-maggie could only hear the heavy - laden branches moving up and down in [the garden]5163-the garden ; a cow lowing ; a bird chirping , and then , to [her]316-maggie delight , the liquid call of an owl going from tree to tree looping them with silver .

[She]316-maggie lay looking at the ceiling . A faint water mark appeared there . It was like [a hill]2310-a hill . It reminded [her]316-maggie of one of [the great desolate mountains in [Greece]114-greece]2911-the great desolate mountains in greece or in [Spain]89-spain , which looked as if [nobody]575-nobody had ever set foot [there]576-there since the beginning of time .

[She]316-maggie opened the book that lay on the counterpane . [She]316-maggie hoped it was [Ruff]391-ruff 's Tour , or the Diary of [a Nobody]2897-a nobody ; but it was [Dante]392-dante , and [she]316-maggie was too lazy to change it . [She]316-maggie read a few lines , here and there . But [her]316-maggie Italian was rusty ; the meaning escaped [her]316-maggie . There was a meaning however ; a hook seemed to scratch the surface of [her]316-maggie mind .

chč per quanti si dice piů lě nostro tanto possiede piů di ben ciascuno .

What did that mean ? [She]316-maggie read the English translation .

For by so many more there are who say ' [ours]2915-ours ' So much the more of good doth [each possess]2916-each possess .

Brushed lightly by [her]316-maggie mind that was watching the moths on the ceiling , and listening to the call of the owl as it looped from tree to tree with its liquid cry , the words did not give out their full meaning , but seemed to hold something furled up in the hard shell of the archaic Italian . [I]0-i 'll read it one of these days , [she]316-maggie thought , shutting the book . When [I]0-i 've pensioned [Crosby]202-crosby off , when . . . . Should [she]316-maggie take [another house]2863-another house ? Should [she]316-maggie travel ? Should [she]316-maggie go to [India]13-india , at last ? [Sir William]377-sir william was getting into bed next door , [his]377-sir william life was over ; [hers]316-maggie was beginning . No , [I]0-i do n't mean to take [another house]2863-another house , not [another house]2863-another house , [she]316-maggie thought , looking at the stain on the ceiling . Again the sense came to [her]316-maggie of [a ship]2920-a ship padding softly through the waves ; of [a train]2489-a train swinging from side to side down [a railway - line]2922-a railway - line . Things ca n't go on for ever , [she]316-maggie thought . Things pass , things change , [she]316-maggie thought , looking up at the ceiling . And where are [we]2923-we going ? Where ? Where ? . . . The moths were dashing round the ceiling ; the book slipped on to the floor . [Craster]384-craster won the pig , but who was it won the silver salver ? [she]316-maggie mused ; made an effort ; turned round , and blew out the candle . Darkness reigned .

1913

It was January . Snow was falling ; snow had fallen all day . The sky spread like a grey goose 's wing from which feathers were falling all over [England]35-england . The sky was nothing but a flurry of falling flakes . [Lanes]2924-lanes were levelled ; hollows filled ; the snow clogged the streams ; obscured windows , and lay wedged against doors . There was a faint murmur in the air , a slight crepitation , as if the air itself were turning to snow ; otherwise all was silent , save when a sheep coughed , snow flopped from a branch , or slipped in an avalanche down some roof in [London]1-london . Now and again a shaft of light spread slowly across the sky as [a car]2494-a car drove through [the muffled roads]2926-the muffled roads . But as the night wore on , snow covered the wheel ruts ; softened to nothingness the marks of the traffic , and coated monuments , [palaces]2927-palaces and statues with a thick vestment of snow .

It was still snowing when [the young man]713-the young man came from [the House Agents]128-the house agents to see over [Abercorn Terrace]18-abercorn terrace . The snow cast a hard white glare upon the walls of [the bathroom]5438-the bathroom , showed up the cracks on the enamel bath , and the stains on the wall . [Eleanor]276-eleanor stood looking out of the window . The trees in [the back garden]572-the back garden were heavily lined with snow ; all the roofs were softly moulded with snow ; it was still falling . [She]276-eleanor turned . [The young man]713-the young man turned too . The light was unbecoming to [them]2923-we both , yet the snow - [she]276-eleanor saw it through the window at the end of [the passage]738-the passage - was beautiful , falling .

[Mr Grice]393-mr grice turned to [her]276-eleanor as [they]2923-we went [downstairs]969-downstairs ,

" The fact is , [[our]2923-we clients]5609-our clients expect more lavatory accommodation nowadays , "[393-mr grice] [he]393-mr grice said , stopping outside [a bedroom]2934-a bedroom door .

Why ca n't [he]393-mr grice say " [baths]5610-baths "[393-mr grice] and have done with it , [she]276-eleanor thought . Slowly [she]276-eleanor went [downstairs]969-downstairs . Now [she]276-eleanor could see the snow falling through the panels of the hall door . As [he]393-mr grice went [downstairs]969-downstairs , [she]276-eleanor noticed the red ears which stood out over [his]393-mr grice high collar ; and the neck which [he]393-mr grice had washed imperfectly in [some sink at [Wandsworth]129-wandsworth]2937-some sink at wandsworth . [She]276-eleanor was annoyed ; as [he]393-mr grice went round [the house]554-the house , sniffing and peering , [he]393-mr grice had indicted [their]2939-their cleanliness , [their]2939-their humanity ; and [he]393-mr grice used absurd long words . [He]393-mr grice was hauling [himself]393-mr grice up into the class above [him]393-mr grice , [she]276-eleanor supposed , by means of long words . Now [he]393-mr grice stepped cautiously over the body of the sleeping dog ; took [his]393-mr grice hat from the hall table , and went down the front door - steps in [[his]393-mr grice business man]2940-his business man 's buttoned boots , leaving yellow footprints in the thick white cushion of snow . [A four - wheeler]2941-a four - wheeler was waiting .

[Eleanor]276-eleanor turned . There was [Crosby]202-crosby , dodging about in [her]202-crosby best bonnet and mantle . [She]202-crosby had been following [Eleanor]276-eleanor about [the house]554-the house like a dog all the morning ; the odious moment could no longer be put off . [[Her]276-eleanor four - wheeler]2943-her four - wheeler was at the door ; [they]2944-they had to say good - bye .

" Well , [Crosby]202-crosby , [it]2945-the empty drawing - room all looks very empty , does n't it ? "[276-eleanor] said [Eleanor]276-eleanor , looking in at [the empty drawing - room]2945-the empty drawing - room . The white light of the snow glared in on the walls . It showed up the marks on the walls where the furniture had stood , where the pictures had hung .

" It does , [Miss Eleanor]276-eleanor , "[202-crosby] said [Crosby]202-crosby . [She]202-crosby stood looking too . [Eleanor]276-eleanor knew that [she]276-eleanor was going to cry . [She]276-eleanor did not want [her]276-eleanor to cry . [She]276-eleanor did not want to cry [herself]276-eleanor .

" [I]202-crosby can still see [you]276-eleanor all sitting round that table , [Miss Eleanor]276-eleanor , "[202-crosby] said [Crosby]202-crosby . But the table had gone . [Morris]237-morris had taken this ; [Delia]201-delia had taken that ; everything had been shared out and separated .

" And the kettle that would n't boil , "[276-eleanor] said [Eleanor]276-eleanor . " D'you remember that ? "[276-eleanor] [She]276-eleanor tried to laugh .

" Oh , [Miss Eleanor]276-eleanor , "[202-crosby] said [Crosby]202-crosby , shaking [her]202-crosby head , " [I]202-crosby remember everything ! "[202-crosby] The tears were forming ; [Eleanor]276-eleanor looked away into [the further room]2946-the further room .

There too were marks on the wall , where the bookcase had stood , where the writing - table had stood . [She]276-eleanor thought of [herself]276-eleanor sitting there , drawing a pattern on the blotting - paper ; digging a hole , adding up [tradesmen]2947-tradesmen 's books . . . . Then [she]276-eleanor turned . There was [Crosby]202-crosby . [Crosby]202-crosby was crying . The mixture of emotions was positively painful ; [she]276-eleanor was so glad to be quit of it all , but for [Crosby]202-crosby it was the end of everything .

[She]276-eleanor had known every cupboard , flagstone , chair and table in [that large rambling house]2948-that large rambling house , not from five or six feet of distance as [they]2949-they had known [it]2948-that large rambling house ; but from [her]276-eleanor knees , as [she]276-eleanor scrubbed and polished ; [she]276-eleanor had known every groove , stain , fork , knife , napkin and cupboard . [They]2949-they and [their]2949-they doings had made [her]276-eleanor entire world . And now [she]276-eleanor was going off , alone , to [a single room at [Richmond]130-richmond]2950-a single room at richmond .

" [I]276-eleanor should think [you]202-crosby 'd be glad to be out of [that basement]5611-that basement anyhow , [Crosby]202-crosby , "[276-eleanor] said [Eleanor]276-eleanor , turning into [the hall]638-the hall again . [She]276-eleanor had never realised how dark , how low [it]638-the hall was , until , looking at [it]638-the hall with " [[our]5612-our [Mr Grice]393-mr grice]5613-our mr grice , "[276-eleanor] [she]276-eleanor had felt ashamed .

" It was [[my]202-crosby home]5614-my home for forty years , [Miss]5414-miss , "[202-crosby] said [Crosby]202-crosby . The tears were running . For forty years ! [Eleanor]276-eleanor thought with a start . [She]276-eleanor had been [a little girl of thirteen or fourteen]2952-a little girl of thirteen or fourteen when [Crosby]202-crosby came to [them]2953-them , looking so stiff and smart . Now [her]276-eleanor blue gnat 's eyes protruded and [her]276-eleanor cheeks were sunk .

[Crosby]202-crosby was stooping to put [Rover]242-rover on the chain .

" [You]202-crosby 're sure [you]202-crosby want [him]242-rover ? "[276-eleanor] said [Eleanor]276-eleanor , looking at the rather smelly , wheezy and unattractive old dog . " [We]2953-them could easily find [a nice home for [him]242-rover in [the country]501-the country]5616-a nice home for him in the country . "[276-eleanor]

" Oh , [miss]5414-miss , do n't ask [me]202-crosby to give [him]242-rover up ! "[202-crosby] said [Crosby]202-crosby . Tears checked [her]276-eleanor speech . Tears were running freely down [her]276-eleanor cheeks . For all [Eleanor]276-eleanor could do to prevent it , tears formed in [her]276-eleanor eyes too .

" [Dear Crosby]202-crosby , good - bye , "[276-eleanor] [she]276-eleanor said . [She]276-eleanor bent and kissed [her]202-crosby . [She]276-eleanor had a curious dry quality of skin [she]276-eleanor noticed . But [her]276-eleanor own tears were falling . Then [Crosby]202-crosby , holding Rover on the chain , began to edge sideways down [the slippery steps]2954-the slippery steps . [Eleanor]276-eleanor , holding the door open , looked after [her]202-crosby . It was a dreadful moment ; unhappy ; muddled ; altogether wrong . [Crosby]202-crosby was so miserable ; [she]276-eleanor was so glad . Yet as [she]276-eleanor held the door open [her]276-eleanor tears formed and fell . [They]2955-they had all lived [here]5159-here ; [she]276-eleanor had stood here to wave [Morris]237-morris to [school]867-school ; there was [the little garden in which [they]2955-they used to plant crocuses]2958-the little garden in which they used to plant crocuses . And now [Crosby]202-crosby , with flakes of snow falling on [her]202-crosby black bonnet , climbed into [the four - wheeler]2959-the four - wheeler , holding [Rover]242-rover in [her]202-crosby arms . [Eleanor]276-eleanor shut the door and went in .

Snow was falling as [the cab]708-the cab trotted along [the streets]1492-the streets . There were long yellow ruts on the pavement where [people]503-people , shopping , had pressed it into slush . It was beginning to thaw slightly ; loads of snow slipped off the roofs and fell onto [the pavement]570-the pavement . [Little boys]2964-little boys , too , were snowballing ; one of [them]2964-little boys threw a ball which struck [the cab]708-the cab as it passed . But when [it]708-the cab turned into [Richmond Green]131-richmond green the whole of [the vast space]2966-the vast space was completely white . [Nobody]575-nobody seemed to have crossed the snow there ; everything was white . The grass was white ; the trees were white ; the railings were white ; the only marks in [the whole vista]2968-the whole vista were the rooks , sitting huddled black on the tree tops . [The cab]708-the cab trotted on .

[The carts]1667-the carts had churned the snow to a yellowish clotted mixture by the time [the cab]708-the cab stopped in front of [the little house]1630-the little house off [the Green]132-the green . [Crosby]202-crosby , carrying [Rover]242-rover in [her]202-crosby arms lest [his]2973-his feet should mark the stairs , went up the steps . There was [Louisa Burt]199-louisa standing to welcome [her]202-crosby ; and [Mr Bishop]394-mr bishop , [the lodger from the top floor]2974-the lodger from the top floor who had been [a butler]2975-a butler . [He]394-mr bishop lent a hand with the luggage , and [Crosby]202-crosby followed after , to [[her]202-crosby little room]2976-her little room .

[[Her]202-crosby room]2890-her room was at the top , and at the back , overlooking [the garden]5163-the garden . [It]2890-her room was small , but when [she]202-crosby had unpacked [her]202-crosby things it was comfortable enough . [It]2890-her room had a look of [Abercorn Terrace]18-abercorn terrace . Indeed for many years [she]202-crosby had been hoarding odds and ends with a view to [her]202-crosby retirement . Indian elephants , silver vases , the walrus that [she]202-crosby had found in the waste - paper basket one morning , when the guns were firing for [the old Queen]2979-the old queen 's funeral - there [they]2980-they all were . [She]202-crosby ranged [them]2980-they askew on the mantelpiece , and when [she]202-crosby had hung the portraits of [the family]1415-the family - some in wedding - dress , some in wigs and gowns , and [Mr Martin]205-martin in [his]205-martin uniform in the middle because [he]205-martin was [her]202-crosby favourite - it was quite like [home]608-home .

But whether it was the change to [Richmond]130-richmond , or whether [he]205-martin had caught cold in the snow , [Rover]242-rover sickened immediately . [He]205-martin refused [his]205-martin food . [His]205-martin nose was hot . [His]205-martin eczema broke out again . When [she]202-crosby tried to take [him]205-martin shopping with [her]202-crosby next morning [he]205-martin rolled over with [his]205-martin feet in the air as if [he]205-martin begged to be left alone . [Mr Bishop]394-mr bishop had to tell [Mrs Crosby]202-crosby - for [she]202-crosby wore the courtesy title in [Richmond]130-richmond - that in [his]394-mr bishop opinion the poor old chap here [he]205-martin patted [his]205-martin head was better out of the way .

" Come along with [me]396-mrs burt , [[my]396-mrs burt dear]5173-my dear , "[396-mrs burt] said [Mrs Burt]396-mrs burt , putting [her]396-mrs burt arm on [Crosby]202-crosby 's shoulder , " and let [Bishop]394-mr bishop do it . "[396-mrs burt]

" [He]394-mr bishop wo n't suffer , [I]394-mr bishop can assure [you]396-mrs burt , "[394-mr bishop] said [Mr Bishop]394-mr bishop , rising from [his]394-mr bishop knees . [He]394-mr bishop had put [her]396-mrs burt Ladyship 's dogs to sleep scores of time before this . " [He]394-mr bishop 'll just take one sniff "[394-mr bishop] - [Mr Bishop]394-mr bishop had [his]394-mr bishop pocket - handkerchief in [his]394-mr bishop hand - " and [he]394-mr bishop 'll be off in a jiffy . "[394-mr bishop]

" It 'll be for [his]394-mr bishop good , [Annie]287-ann , "[396-mrs burt] [Mrs Burt]396-mrs burt added , trying to draw [her]396-mrs burt away .

Indeed , the poor old dog looked very miserable . But [Crosby]202-crosby shook [her]396-mrs burt head . [He]394-mr bishop had wagged [his]394-mr bishop tail ; [his]394-mr bishop eyes were open . [He]394-mr bishop was alive . There was a gleam of what [she]396-mrs burt had long considered a smile on [his]394-mr bishop face . [He]394-mr bishop depended on [her]396-mrs burt , [she]396-mrs burt felt . [She]396-mrs burt was not going to hand [him]394-mr bishop over to [strangers]2983-strangers . [She]396-mrs burt sat by [his]394-mr bishop side for three days and nights ; [she]396-mrs burt fed [him]394-mr bishop with a teaspoon on [Brand]194-brand 's Essence ; but at last [he]394-mr bishop refused to open [his]394-mr bishop lips ; [his]394-mr bishop body grew stiffer and stiffer ; a fly walked across [his]394-mr bishop nose without its twitching . This was in the early morning with the sparrows twittering on the trees outside .

" It 's a mercy [she]396-mrs burt 's got something to distract [her]396-mrs burt , "[396-mrs burt] said [Mrs Burt]396-mrs burt as [Crosby]202-crosby passed the [kitchen]2984-kitchen window the day after the funeral in [her]202-crosby best mantle and bonnet ; for it was Thursday , when [she]202-crosby fetched [Mr Pargiter]337-mr pargiter 's socks from [Ebury Street]133-ebury street . " But [he]394-mr bishop ought to have been put down long ago , "[202-crosby] [she]202-crosby added , turning back to the sink . [His]394-mr bishop breath had smelt .

[Crosby]202-crosby took [the District Railway]2985-the district railway to [Sloane Square]134-sloane square and then [she]202-crosby walked . [She]202-crosby walked slowly , with [her]202-crosby elbows jutting out from [her]202-crosby sides as if to protect [herself]202-crosby from the haphazardry of [the streets]1492-the streets . [She]202-crosby still looked sad ; but the change from [Richmond]130-richmond to [Ebury Street]133-ebury street did [her]202-crosby good . [She]202-crosby felt more [herself]202-crosby in [Ebury Street]133-ebury street than in [Richmond]130-richmond . [A common sort of [people]503-people]2987-a common sort of people lived in [Richmond]130-richmond [she]202-crosby always felt . Here [the ladies and gentlemen]2989-the ladies and gentlemen had the same kind of way with [them]2989-the ladies and gentlemen . [She]202-crosby glanced approvingly into [the shops]1428-the shops as [she]202-crosby passed . And [General Arbuthnot]307-arbuthnot , who used to visit [the Master]1137-the master , lived in [Ebury Street]133-ebury street [she]202-crosby reflected as [she]202-crosby turned into [that gloomy thoroughfare]2992-that gloomy thoroughfare . [He]307-arbuthnot was dead now ; [Louisa]199-louisa had shown [her]202-crosby the notice in the papers . But when [he]307-arbuthnot was alive , [he]307-arbuthnot had lived [here]5159-here . [She]202-crosby had reached [[Mr Martin]205-martin 's lodgings]2994-mr martin 's lodgings . [She]202-crosby paused on the steps and adjusted [her]202-crosby bonnet . [She]202-crosby always had a word with [Martin]205-martin when [she]202-crosby came to fetch [his]205-martin socks ; it was one of [her]202-crosby pleasures ; and [she]202-crosby enjoyed a gossip with [Mrs Briggs]397-mrs briggs , [[his]205-martin landlady]2995-his landlady . Today [she]202-crosby would have the pleasure of telling [her]397-mrs briggs of the death of [Rover]242-rover . Sidling cautiously down [the area steps]2996-the area steps which were slippery with sleet [she]202-crosby stood at the back door and rang the bell .

[Martin]205-martin sat in [[his]205-martin room]2997-his room reading [his]205-martin newspaper . The war in [the Balkans]123-the balkans was over ; but there was more trouble brewing - that [he]205-martin was sure . Quite sure . [He]205-martin turned the page . [The room]577-the room was very dark with the sleet falling . And [he]205-martin could never read while [he]205-martin was waiting . [Crosby]202-crosby was coming ; [he]205-martin could hear voices in [the hall]638-the hall . How [they]3000-they gossiped ! How [they]3000-they chattered ! [he]205-martin thought impatiently . [He]205-martin threw the paper down and waited . Now [she]202-crosby was coming ; [her]202-crosby hand was on the door . But what was [he]205-martin to say to [her]202-crosby ? [he]205-martin wondered , as [he]205-martin saw the handle turning . [He]205-martin put down the paper . [He]205-martin made use of the usual formula : " Well , [Crosby]202-crosby , how 's [the world]5285-the world treating [you]202-crosby ? "[205-martin] as [she]202-crosby came in .

[She]202-crosby remembered [Rover]242-rover ; and the tears started to [her]202-crosby eyes .

" A burn , [sir]5200-sir , "[202-crosby] [she]202-crosby said with conviction .

" Tut - tut - tut ! "[202-crosby] [she]202-crosby said , shaking [her]202-crosby head .

[Crosby]202-crosby cast [her]202-crosby eye round [the room]577-the room . It was a lie . [He]205-martin had no engagement . [One]847-one always lies to [servants]2849-servants , [he]205-martin thought , looking out of the window . Then as [he]205-martin stood at the window looking at [the little figures slinking along the wet pavement]3031-the little figures slinking along the wet pavement [he]205-martin saw [Crosby]202-crosby come up [the area steps]2996-the area steps with a parcel under [her]202-crosby arm . 1914

It was a brilliant spring ; the day was radiant . Even the air seemed to have a burr in it as it touched the tree tops ; it vibrated , it rippled . The leaves were sharp and green . In [the country old church]3034-the country old church clocks rasped out the hour ; the rusty sound went over fields that were red with clover , and up went [the rooks as if flung by the bells]3035-the rooks as if flung by the bells . Round [they]3036-they wheeled ; then settled on the tree tops .

In [London]1-london all was gallant and strident ; the season was beginning ; horns hooted ; the traffic roared ; flags flew taut as trout in a stream . And from all the spires of all [the London churches]3037-the london churches - [the fashionable saints of [Mayfair]81-mayfair]3038-the fashionable saints of mayfair , [the dowdy saints of [Kensington]83-kensington]3039-the dowdy saints of kensington , [the hoary saints of [the city]5310-the city]3040-the hoary saints of the city - the hour was proclaimed . The air over [London]1-london seemed a rough sea of sound through which circles travelled . But the clocks were irregular , as if [the saints themselves]3042-the saints themselves were divided . There were pauses , silences . . . . Then the clocks struck again .

Here in [Ebury Street]133-ebury street some distant frail - voiced clock was striking . It was eleven . [Martin]205-martin , standing at [his]205-martin window , looked down on [the narrow street]2521-the narrow street . The sun was bright ; [he]205-martin was in the best of spirits ; [he]205-martin was going to visit [[his]205-martin stockbroker]3044-his stockbroker in [the city]5310-the city . [His]205-martin affairs were turning out well . At one time , [he]205-martin was thinking , [[his]205-martin father]639-his father had made a lot of money ; then [he]639-his father lost it ; then [he]639-his father made it ; but in the end [he]639-his father had done very well .

[He]205-martin stood at the window for a moment admiring [a lady of fashion in a charming hat]3047-a lady of fashion in a charming hat who was looking at a pot in [the curiosity shop opposite]3048-the curiosity shop opposite . It was a blue pot on a Chinese stand with green brocade behind it . The sloping symmetrical body , the depth of blue , the little cracks in the glaze pleased [him]205-martin . And [the lady looking at the pot]3049-the lady looking at the pot was also charming .

[He]205-martin took [his]205-martin hat and stick and went out into [the street]587-the street . [He]205-martin would walk part of the way to [the City]5310-the city . " [The King of [[Spain]89-spain 's daughter]5412-spain 's daughter]5411-the king of spain 's daughter "[205-martin] [he]205-martin hummed as [he]205-martin turned up [Sloane Street]136-sloane street , " came to visit [me]205-martin . All for the sake of . . . . "[205-martin] [He]205-martin looked into [the shop]1641-the shop windows as [he]205-martin passed . [They]3053-they were full of summer dresses ; charming confections of green and gauze , and there were flights of hats stuck on little rods . " . . . all for the sake of "[205-martin] [he]205-martin hummed as [he]205-martin walked on , " [my]205-martin silver nutmeg tree . "[205-martin] But what was a silver nutmeg tree [he]205-martin wondered ? An organ was fluting its merry little jig further down [the street]587-the street . The organ moved round and round , shifted this way and that , as if [the old man who played it]3055-the old man who played it were half dancing to the tune . [A pretty servant girl]3056-a pretty servant girl ran up the area steps and gave [him]205-martin a penny . [His]205-martin supple Italian face wrinkled all over as [he]205-martin whipped off [his]205-martin cap and bowed to [her]3056-a pretty servant girl . [The girl]1220-the girl smiled and slipped back into [the kitchen]620-the kitchen .

" . . . all for the sake of [my]205-martin silver nutmeg tree "[205-martin] [Martin]205-martin hummed , peering down through the area railings into [the kitchen]620-the kitchen where [they]3060-they were sitting . [They]3060-they looked very snug , with teapots and bread and butter on the kitchen table . [His]205-martin stick swung from side to side like the tail of a cheerful dog . [Everybody]547-everybody seemed light - hearted and irresponsible , sallying out of [[their]547-everybody houses]3062-their houses , flaunting along [the streets]1492-the streets with pennies for [the organ - grinders]3064-the organ - grinders and pennies for [the beggars]3065-the beggars . [Everybody]547-everybody seemed to have money to spend . [Women]1429-women clustered round the plate - glass windows . [He]205-martin too stopped , looked at the model of [a toy boat]3068-a toy boat ; at dressing - cases , shining yellow with rows of silver bottles . But who wrote that song , [he]205-martin wondered , as [he]205-martin strolled on , about [the King of [[Spain]89-spain 's daughter]5412-spain 's daughter]5411-the king of spain 's daughter , the song that [Pippy]238-pippy used to sing [him]205-martin , as [she]238-pippy wiped [his]205-martin ears with a piece of slimy flannel ? "[238-pippy] And then suddenly [her]238-pippy knee gave , and down [he]205-martin was tumbled onto the floor .

Here [he]205-martin was at [Hyde Park Corner]137-hyde park corner . The scene was extremely animated . [Vans]3071-vans , [motor - cars]3072-motor - cars , [motor omnibuses]3073-motor omnibuses were streaming down [the hill]2350-the hill . The trees in [the Park]562-the park had little green leaves on them . Cars with [gay ladies in pale dresses]3076-gay ladies in pale dresses were already passing in at the gates . [Everybody]547-everybody was going about [their]547-everybody business . " To [St. Paul 's]45-st. paul 's , "[205-martin] [he]205-martin said , handing [the conductor]1668-the conductor [his]205-martin coppers .

[The omnibuses]3083-the omnibuses swirled and circled in a perpetual current round [the steps of [St. Paul 's]45-st. paul 's]3084-the steps of st. paul 's . The statue of [Queen Anne]401-queen anne seemed to preside over the chaos and to supply it with a centre , like the hub of a wheel . It seemed as if [the white lady]3085-the white lady ruled the traffic with [her]3085-the white lady sceptre ; directed the activities of [the little men in bowler hats and round coats]3086-the little men in bowler hats and round coats ; of [the women carrying attaché cases]3087-the women carrying attaché cases ; of [the vans]3088-the vans , [the lorries]3089-the lorries and [the motor omnibuses]3090-the motor omnibuses . The doors of [the Cathedral]3093-the cathedral kept opening and shutting . Now and again a blast of faint organ music was blown out into the air . The pigeons waddled ; the sparrows fluttered . Soon after midday [a little old man carrying a paper bag]3094-a little old man carrying a paper bag took up [his]3094-a little old man carrying a paper bag station half - way up the steps and proceeded to feed the birds . [He]3094-a little old man carrying a paper bag held out a slice of bread . [His]3094-a little old man carrying a paper bag lips moved . [He]3094-a little old man carrying a paper bag seemed to be wheedling and coaxing [them]3095-them . Soon [he]3094-a little old man carrying a paper bag was haloed by a circle of fluttering wings . [A little crowd]3096-a little crowd gathered to watch [him]3094-a little old man carrying a paper bag feeding the sparrows . [He]3094-a little old man carrying a paper bag tossed [his]3094-a little old man carrying a paper bag bread round [him]3094-a little old man carrying a paper bag in a circle . Then there was a ripple in the air . The great clock , all the clocks of [the city]5310-the city , seemed to be gathering [their]3098-their forces together ; [they]3098-their seemed to be whirring a preliminary warning . Then the stroke struck . " One "[3098-their] blared out . All the sparrows fluttered up into the air ; even the pigeons were frightened ; some of [them]3099-them made a little flight round the head of [Queen Anne]401-queen anne .

As the last ripple of the stroke died away , [Martin]205-martin came out in [the open space in front of [the Cathedral]3093-the cathedral]3100-the open space in front of the cathedral .

[He]205-martin crossed over and stood with [his]205-martin back against a shop window looking up at the great dome . All the weights in [his]205-martin body seemed to shift . [He]205-martin had a curious sense of something moving in [his]205-martin body in harmony with [the building]1079-the building ; it righted itself : it came to a full stop . It was exciting - this change of proportion . [He]205-martin wished [he]205-martin had been [an architect]2336-an architect . [He]205-martin stood with [his]205-martin back pressed against [the shop]1641-the shop trying to get the whole of [the cathedral]3093-the cathedral clear . But it was difficult with [so many people]3106-so many people passing . [They]3106-so many people knocked against [him]205-martin and brushed in front of [him]205-martin . It was the rush hour , of course , when [City men]3107-city men were making for [their]3107-city men luncheons . [They]3107-city men were taking short cuts across [the steps]3108-the steps . The scene since the morning had changed slightly . Clocks in the distance were just striking three . The wind , coming from the west , moved white clouds grained with gold across the sky . The windows of [Park Lane]93-park lane shone with blue and gold reflections .

[Martin]205-martin stepped out briskly .

[Waitresses]3272-waitresses were hurrying in and out with trays ; the season had begun . The scene was very gay .

[A lady]3239-a lady , fashionably dressed with a purple feather dipping down on one side of [her]3239-a lady hat , sat there sipping an ice . [Sara]344-sara had walked on . [She]344-sara too was netted with floating lights from between the leaves . A primal innocence seemed to brood over the scene . The birds made a fitful sweet chirping in the branches ; the roar of [London]1-london encircled the open space in a ring of distant but complete sound . The pink and white chestnut blossoms rode up and down as the branches moved in the breeze . " Before [I]205-martin met [her]3311-the baby at [St. Paul 's]45-st. paul 's , "[205-martin] [he]205-martin said . [They]3310-them were silent . [The boats]3305-the boats were sailing ; [the men]1466-the men walking ; [the little boys]3317-the little boys dabbled in [the pond]3291-the pond for minnows ; the waters of [the pond]3291-the pond rippled bright blue . Everything was full of the stir , the potency , the fecundity of spring .

Suddenly [he]205-martin said aloud :

" Possessiveness is the devil . "[205-martin]

[Maggie]316-maggie looked at [him]205-martin . Did [he]205-martin mean [herself]316-maggie - [herself]316-maggie and [the baby]3311-the baby ? No . There was a tone in [his]205-martin voice that told [her]316-maggie [he]205-martin was thinking not of [her]316-maggie .

" What are [you]205-martin thinking ? "[316-maggie] [she]316-maggie asked .

" About [the woman [I]205-martin 'm in love with]5704-the woman i 'm in love with , "[205-martin] [he]205-martin said . " Love ought to stop on both sides , do n't [you]316-maggie think , simultaneously ? "[205-martin] [He]205-martin spoke without any stress on the words , so as not to wake [the sleepers]3321-the sleepers . " But it wo n't - that 's the devil , "[205-martin] [he]205-martin added in the same undertone .

" Bored , are [you]205-martin ? "[316-maggie] [she]316-maggie murmured .

" Stiff , "[205-martin] [he]205-martin said . " Bored stiff . "[205-martin] [He]205-martin stooped and disinterred a pebble in the grass .

" And jealous ? "[316-maggie] [she]316-maggie murmured . [Her]316-maggie voice was very low and soft .

" A very brilliant party , [Lady Lasswade]313-lady lasswade , "[205-martin] [he]205-martin said with [his]205-martin usual tiresome irony .

[She]254-kitty sat still for a moment in [[her]254-kitty brightly lit compartment]3614-her brightly lit compartment ; then [she]254-kitty tugged the blind and it sprang up with a jerk . Elongated lights slid past ; lights in [factories]3615-factories and [warehouses]3616-warehouses ; lights in [obscure back streets]3617-obscure back streets . Then there were [asphalt paths]2666-asphalt paths ; more lights in [public gardens]3619-public gardens ; and then bushes and a hedge in [a field]958-a field . [They]3621-they were leaving [London]1-london behind [them]3621-they ; leaving that blaze of light which seemed , as [the train]2673-the train rushed into the darkness , to contract itself into one fiery circle . [The train]2673-the train rushed with a roar through [a tunnel]3624-a tunnel . [It]2673-the train seemed to perform an act of amputation ; now [she]254-kitty was cut off from that circle of light .

[She]254-kitty looked round [the narrow little compartment in which [she]254-kitty was isolated]3625-the narrow little compartment in which she was isolated . Everything shook slightly . There was a perpetual faint vibration . [She]254-kitty seemed to be passing from [one world]3626-one world to another ; this was the moment of transition . [She]254-kitty sat still for a moment ; then undressed and paused with [her]254-kitty hand on the blind . [The train]2673-the train had got into its stride now ; it was rushing at full speed through [the country]501-the country . A few distant lights twinkled here and there . Black clumps of trees stood in [the grey summer fields]3629-the grey summer fields ; [the fields]502-the fields were full of summer grasses . The light from the engine lit up a quiet group of cows ; and a hedge of hawthorn . [They]3621-they were in [open country]1312-open country now .

[She]254-kitty pulled down the blind and climbed into [her]254-kitty bed . [She]254-kitty laid [herself]254-kitty out on the rather hard shelf with [her]254-kitty back to the carriage wall , so that [she]254-kitty felt a faint vibration against [her]254-kitty head . [She]254-kitty lay listening to the humming noise which [the train]2673-the train made , now that it had got into its stride . Smoothly and powerfully [she]254-kitty was being drawn through [England]35-england to [the north]1293-the north . [I]0-i need do nothing , [she]254-kitty thought , nothing , nothing , but let [myself]0-i be drawn on . [She]254-kitty turned and pulled the blue shade over the lamp . The sound of [the train]2673-the train became louder in the darkness ; its roar , its vibration , seemed to fall into a regular rhythm of sound , raking through [her]254-kitty mind , rolling out [her]254-kitty thoughts .

Ah , but not all of them , [she]254-kitty thought , turning restlessly on [her]254-kitty shelf . Some still jutted up . [One]847-one 's not [a child]1713-a child , [she]254-kitty thought , staring at the light under the blue shade , any longer . The years changed things ; destroyed things ; heaped things up - worries and bothers ; here they were again . Fragments of talk kept coming back to [her]254-kitty ; sights came before [her]254-kitty . [She]254-kitty saw [herself]254-kitty raise the window with a jerk ; and the bristles on [Aunt Warburton]419-aunt warburton 's chin . [She]254-kitty saw [the women]1465-the women rising , and [the men]1466-the men filing in . [She]254-kitty sighed as [she]254-kitty turned on [her]254-kitty ledge . All [their]3639-their clothes are the same , [she]254-kitty thought ; all [their]3639-their lives are the same . And which is right ? [she]254-kitty thought , turning restlessly on [her]254-kitty shelf . Which is wrong ? [She]254-kitty turned again .

[The train]2673-the train rushed [her]254-kitty on . The sound had deepened ; it had become a continuous roar . How could [she]254-kitty sleep ? How could [she]254-kitty prevent [herself]254-kitty from thinking ? [She]254-kitty turned away from the light . NOW where are [we]3641-we ? [she]254-kitty said to [herself]254-kitty . Where is [the train]2673-the train at this moment ? NOW , [she]254-kitty murmured , shutting [her]254-kitty eyes , [we]3641-we are passing [the white house]3643-the white house on [the hill]2350-the hill ; NOW [we]3641-we are going through [the tunnel]3645-the tunnel ; NOW [we]3641-we are crossing the bridge over [the river]813-the river . . . . A blank intervened ; [her]254-kitty thoughts became spaced ; they became muddled . Past and present became jumbled together . [She]254-kitty saw [Margaret Marrable]422-margaret marrable pinching the dress in [her]422-margaret marrable fingers , but [she]422-margaret marrable was leading a bull with a ring through its nose . . . . This is sleep , [she]254-kitty said to [herself]254-kitty , half opening [her]254-kitty eyes ; thank goodness , [she]254-kitty said to [herself]254-kitty , shutting them again , this is sleep . And [she]254-kitty resigned [herself]254-kitty to the charge of [the train]2673-the train , whose roar now became dulled and distant .

There was a tap at [her]254-kitty door . [She]254-kitty lay for a moment , wondering why [the room]577-the room shook so ; then the scene settled itself ; [she]254-kitty was in [the train]2673-the train ; [she]254-kitty was in [the country]501-the country ; [they]3651-they were nearing [the station]1884-the station . [She]254-kitty got up .

[She]254-kitty dressed rapidly and stood in [the corridor]2536-the corridor . It was still early . [She]254-kitty watched the fields galloping past . They were [the bare fields]3654-the bare fields , [the angular fields of [the north]1293-the north]3655-the angular fields of the north . The spring was late here ; the trees were not fully out yet . The smoke looped down and caught a tree in its white cloud . When it lifted , [she]254-kitty thought how fine the light was ; clear and sharp , white and grey . [The land]500-the land had none of the softness , none of the greenness of [the land in the south]3658-the land in the south . But here was [the junction]3659-the junction ; here was the gasometer ; [they]3651-they were running into [the station]1884-the station . [The train]2673-the train slowed down , and all the lamp - posts on [the platform]755-the platform gradually came to a standstill .

[She]254-kitty got out and drew in a deep breath of the cold raw air . [The car]2512-the car was waiting for [her]254-kitty ; and directly [she]254-kitty saw it [she]254-kitty remembered - it was [the new car]3664-the new car ; a birthday present from [[her]254-kitty husband]1135-her husband . [She]254-kitty had never driven in [it]2512-the car yet . [Cole]431-nicholas touched [his]431-nicholas hat .

" Let 's have it open , [Cole]431-nicholas , "[254-kitty] [she]254-kitty said , and [he]431-nicholas opened the stiff new hood , and [she]254-kitty got in beside [him]431-nicholas . Very slowly , for the engine seemed to beat intermittently , starting and stopping and then starting again , [they]3666-they moved off . [They]3666-they drove through [the town]3580-the town ; all [the shops]1428-the shops were still shut ; [women]1429-women were on [their]1429-women knees scrubbing doorsteps ; blinds were still drawn in [bedrooms]3670-bedrooms and [sitting - rooms]3671-sitting - rooms ; there was very little traffic about . Only [milk - carts]3672-milk - carts rattled past . Dogs roamed down the middle of [the street]587-the street on private errands of [their]3674-their own . [Cole]431-nicholas had to hoot again and again .

" [They]3666-they 'll learn in time , [m'lady]5746-m'lady , "[431-nicholas] [he]431-nicholas said as a great brindled cur slunk out of [their]3666-they way . In [the town]3580-the town [he]431-nicholas drove carefully ; but once [they]3666-they were outside [he]431-nicholas speeded up . [Kitty]254-kitty watched the needle jump forward on the speedometer .

" [She]254-kitty does it easily ? "[254-kitty] [she]254-kitty asked , listening to the soft purr of the engine .

[Cole]431-nicholas lifted [his]431-nicholas foot to show how lightly it touched the accelerator . Then [he]431-nicholas touched it again and [the car]2512-the car sped on . [They]3666-they were driving too fast , [Kitty]254-kitty thought ; but [the road]705-the road - [she]254-kitty kept [her]254-kitty eye on [it]705-the road - was still empty . [Only two or three lumbering farm waggons]3678-only two or three lumbering farm waggons passed [them]3666-they ; [the men]1466-the men went to the horses ' heads and held [them]3680-them as [they]1466-the men went by . [The road]705-the road stretched pearl - white in front of [them]3666-they ; the hedges were decked with the little pointed leaves of early spring .

" Spring 's very late up here , "[254-kitty] said [Kitty]254-kitty ; " cold winds [I]254-kitty suppose ? "[254-kitty]

[Cole]431-nicholas nodded . [He]431-nicholas had none of the servile ways of the [London flunkey]1-london ; [she]254-kitty was at [her]254-kitty ease with [him]431-nicholas ; [she]254-kitty could be silent . The air seemed to have different grades of warmth and chill in it ; now sweet ; now - [they]3666-they were passing [a farmyard]3682-a farmyard - strong - smelling , acrid from the sour smell of manure . [She]254-kitty leant back , holding [her]254-kitty hat to [her]254-kitty head as [they]3666-they rushed [a hill]2310-a hill . " [You]431-nicholas wo n't get [her]254-kitty up this on top , [Cole]431-nicholas , "[254-kitty] [she]254-kitty said . The pace slackened a little ; [they]3666-they were climbing [the familiar Crabbs hill]3684-the familiar crabbs hill , with the yellow streaks where [carters]3685-carters had put on [their]3685-carters brakes . In the old days , when [she]254-kitty drove [horses]2655-horses , [they]2655-horses used to get out here and walk . [Cole]431-nicholas said nothing . [He]431-nicholas was going to show off [his]431-nicholas engine , [she]254-kitty suspected . [The car]2512-the car swept up finely . But [the hill]2350-the hill was long ; there was a level stretch ; then [the road]705-the road mounted again . [The car]2512-the car faltered . [Cole]431-nicholas coaxed [her]254-kitty on . [Kitty]254-kitty saw [him]431-nicholas jerk [his]431-nicholas body slightly backwards and forwards as if [he]431-nicholas were encouraging horses . [She]254-kitty felt the tension of [his]431-nicholas muscles . [They]2655-horses slowed - [they]2655-horses almost stopped . No , now [they]2655-horses were on [the crest of [the hill]2350-the hill]3691-the crest of the hill . [She]254-kitty had done it on top !

" Well done ! "[254-kitty] [she]254-kitty exclaimed . [He]431-nicholas said nothing ; but [he]431-nicholas was very proud , [she]254-kitty knew .

" [We]2655-horses could n't have done that on [the old car]5754-the old car , "[254-kitty] [she]254-kitty said .

" Ah , but it was n't [her]3696-the mad lady fault , "[431-nicholas] said [Cole]431-nicholas .

[He]431-nicholas was [a very humane man]3693-a very humane man ; [the kind of man [she]254-kitty liked]3694-the kind of man she liked , [she]254-kitty reflected - silent , reserved . On [they]2655-horses swept again . Now [they]2655-horses were passing [the grey stone house where [the mad lady]3696-the mad lady lived alone with [her]3696-the mad lady peacocks and [her]3696-the mad lady bloodhounds]3695-the grey stone house where the mad lady lived alone with her peacocks and her bloodhounds . [They]2655-horses had passed [it]3695-the grey stone house where the mad lady lived alone with her peacocks and her bloodhounds . Now [the woods]1506-the woods were on [their]2655-horses right hand and the air came singing through [them]2655-horses . It was like [the sea]1514-the sea , [Kitty]254-kitty thought , looking , as [they]2655-horses passed , down [a dark green drive patched with yellow sunlight]3699-a dark green drive patched with yellow sunlight . On [they]2655-horses went again . Now heaps of ruddy brown leaves lay by the roadside staining the puddles red .

" It 's been raining ? "[254-kitty] [she]254-kitty said . [He]3700-he nodded . [They]2655-horses came out on [the high ridge with woods beneath]3701-the high ridge with woods beneath and there , in [a clearing among the trees]3702-a clearing among the trees , was [the grey tower of the Castle]3703-the grey tower of the castle . [She]254-kitty always looked for it and greeted [it]3703-the grey tower of the castle as if [she]254-kitty were raising a hand to [a friend]5462-a friend . [They]2655-horses were on [[their]2655-horses own land]3705-their own land now . Gateposts were branded with [their]2655-horses initials ; [their]2655-horses arms swung above the doorways of [inns]3706-inns ; [their]2655-horses crest was mounted over cottage doors . [Cole]431-nicholas looked at the clock . The needle leapt again .

Too fast , too fast ! [Kitty]254-kitty said to [herself]254-kitty . But [she]254-kitty liked the rush of the wind in [her]254-kitty face . Now [they]2655-horses reached [the Lodge gate]3707-the lodge gate ; [Mrs Preedy]432-mrs preedy was holding it open with [a white - haired child on [her]432-mrs preedy arm]3708-a white - haired child on her arm . [They]2655-horses rushed through [the Park]562-the park . [The deer]3710-the deer looked up and hopped away lightly through the fern .

" Two minutes under the quarter , [m'lady]5746-m'lady , "[431-nicholas] said [Cole]431-nicholas as [they]2655-horses swept in a circle and drew up at the door . [Kitty]254-kitty stood for a moment looking at [the car]2512-the car . [She]254-kitty laid [her]254-kitty hand on the bonnet . It was hot . [She]254-kitty gave it a little pat . " [She]254-kitty did it beautifully , [Cole]431-nicholas , "[254-kitty] [she]254-kitty said . " [I]254-kitty 'll tell [[his]431-nicholas Lordship]1773-his lordship . "[254-kitty] [Cole]431-nicholas smiled ; [he]431-nicholas was happy .

[She]254-kitty went in . [Nobody]575-nobody was about ; [they]2655-horses had arrived earlier than was expected . [She]254-kitty crossed [the great stone - flagged hall]3713-the great stone - flagged hall , with the armour and the busts , and went into [the morning - room where breakfast was laid]3714-the morning - room where breakfast was laid .

The green light dazzled [her]254-kitty as [she]254-kitty went in . It was as if [she]254-kitty stood in the hollow of an emerald . All was green outside . [The statues of grey French ladies]3715-the statues of grey french ladies stood on [the terrace]1499-the terrace , holding [their]3715-the statues of grey french ladies baskets ; but the baskets were empty . In summer flowers would burn there . Green turf fell down in broad swaths between clipped yews ; dipped to [the river]813-the river ; and then rose again to [the hill that was crested with woods]3718-the hill that was crested with woods . There was a curl of mist on [the woods]1506-the woods now - the light mist of early morning . As [she]254-kitty gazed a bee buzzed in [her]254-kitty ear ; [she]254-kitty thought [she]254-kitty heard the murmur of [the river]813-the river over the stones ; pigeons crooned in the tree tops . It was the voice of early morning , the voice of summer . But the door opened . Here was breakfast .

[She]254-kitty breakfasted ; [she]254-kitty felt warm , stored , and comfortable as [she]254-kitty lay back in [her]254-kitty chair . And [she]254-kitty had nothing to do - nothing whatever . The whole day was [hers]254-kitty . It was fine too . The sunlight suddenly quickened in [the room]577-the room , and laid a broad bar of light across the floor . The sun was on the flowers outside . A tortoiseshell butterfly flaunted across the window ; [she]254-kitty saw it settle on a leaf , and there it sat , opening its wings and shutting them , opening and shutting them , as if it feasted on the sunlight . [She]254-kitty watched it . The down was soft rust - red on its wings . Off it flaunted again . Then , admitted by an invisible hand , [the chow]3722-the chow stalked in ; came straight up to [her]254-kitty ; sniffed at [her]254-kitty skirt , and flung [himself]3722-the chow down in a bright patch of sunlight .

[Heartless brute]3723-heartless brute ! [she]254-kitty thought , but [his]3722-the chow indifference pleased [her]254-kitty . [He]3722-the chow asked nothing of [her]254-kitty either . [She]254-kitty stretched [her]254-kitty hand for a cigarette . And what would [Martin]205-martin say , [she]254-kitty wondered , as [she]254-kitty took the enamel box that turned from green to blue , as [she]254-kitty opened it . Hideous ? Vulgar ? Possibly - but what did it matter what [people]503-people said ? [Criticism]433-criticism seemed light as smoke this morning . What did it matter what [he]3722-the chow said , what [they]503-people said , what [anybody]990-anybody said , since [she]254-kitty had a whole day to [herself]254-kitty ? - since [she]254-kitty was alone ? And there [they]503-people are , still asleep , in [[their]503-people houses]3062-their houses , [she]254-kitty thought , standing at the window , looking at the green - grey grass , after [their]503-people dances , after [their]503-people parties . . . The thought pleased [her]254-kitty . [She]254-kitty threw away [her]254-kitty cigarette and went [upstairs]684-upstairs to change [her]254-kitty clothes .

The sun was much stronger when [she]254-kitty came down again . [The garden]5163-the garden had already lost its look of purity ; the mist was off [the woods]1506-the woods . [She]254-kitty could hear the squeak of the lawn mower as [she]254-kitty stepped out of the window . The rubber - shoed pony was pacing up and down [the lawns]3730-the lawns leaving a pale wake in the grass behind [him]3731-him . The birds were singing in their scattered way . The starlings in [their]3732-their bright mail were feeding on the grass . Dew shone , red , violet , gold on the trembling tips of the grass blades . It was a perfect May morning .

[She]254-kitty sauntered slowly along [the terrace]1499-the terrace . As [she]254-kitty passed [she]254-kitty glanced in at the long windows of [the library]3734-the library . Everything was shrouded and shut up . But [the long room]3735-the long room looked more than usually stately , [its]3735-the long room proportions seemly ; and the brown books in their long rows seemed to exist silently , with dignity , by [themselves]3736-themselves , for [themselves]3736-themselves . [She]254-kitty left [the terrace]1499-the terrace and strolled down the long grass path . [The garden]5163-the garden was still empty ; [only a man in [his]3739-only a man in his shirt sleeves shirt sleeves]3739-only a man in his shirt sleeves was doing something to a tree ; but [she]254-kitty need speak to [nobody]575-nobody . [The chow]3722-the chow stalked after [her]254-kitty ; [he]3722-the chow too was silent . [She]254-kitty walked on past the flower - beds to [the river]813-the river . There [she]254-kitty always stopped , on [the bridge]2062-the bridge , with the cannon - balls at intervals . The water always fascinated [her]254-kitty . [The quick northern river]3744-the quick northern river came down from [the moors]5250-the moors ; it was never smooth and green , never deep and placid like [southern rivers]3746-southern rivers . It raced ; it hurried . It splayed itself , red , yellow and clear brown , over the pebbles on the bed . Resting [her]254-kitty elbows on the balustrade , [she]254-kitty watched it eddy round the arches ; [she]254-kitty watched it make diamonds and sharp arrow streaks over the stones . [She]254-kitty listened . [She]254-kitty knew the different sounds it made in summer and winter ; now it hurried , it raced .

But [the chow]3722-the chow was bored ; [he]3722-the chow marched on . [She]254-kitty followed [him]3722-the chow . [She]254-kitty went up [the green ride]3748-the green ride towards the snuffer - shaped monument on [the crest of [the hill]2350-the hill]3691-the crest of the hill . [Every path]3751-every path through [the woods]1506-the woods had its name . There was [[Keepers]434-keepers ' Path]3753-keepers ' path , [Lovers]3754-lovers ' Walk , [Ladies]1142-ladies ' Mile , and here was [[the Earl]3756-the earl 's Ride]3757-the earl 's ride . But before [she]254-kitty went into [the woods]1506-the woods , [she]254-kitty stopped and looked back at [the house]554-the house . Times out of number [she]254-kitty had stopped [here]5159-here ; [the Castle]3761-the castle looked grey and stately ; asleep this morning , with the blinds drawn , and no flag on the flagstaff . Very noble [it]3761-the castle looked , and ancient , and enduring . Then [she]254-kitty went on into [the woods]1506-the woods .

The wind seemed to rise as [she]254-kitty walked under the trees . It sang in their tops , but it was silent beneath . The dead leaves crackled under foot ; among them sprang up the pale spring flowers , the loveliest of the year - blue flowers and white flowers , trembling on cushions of green moss . Spring was sad always , [she]254-kitty thought ; it brought back memories . All passes , all changes , [she]254-kitty thought , as [she]254-kitty climbed up [the little path between the trees]3763-the little path between the trees . Nothing of this belonged to [her]254-kitty ; [[her]254-kitty son]2246-her son would inherit ; [[his]2246-her son wife]550-his wife would walk here after [her]254-kitty . [She]254-kitty broke off a twig ; [she]254-kitty picked a flower and put it to [her]254-kitty lips . But [she]254-kitty was in the prime of life ; [she]254-kitty was vigorous . [She]254-kitty strode on . [The ground]3344-the ground rose sharply ; [her]254-kitty muscles felt strong and flexible as [she]254-kitty pressed [her]254-kitty thick - soled shoes to the ground . [She]254-kitty threw away [her]254-kitty flower . [The trees]3767-the trees thinned as [she]254-kitty strode higher and higher . Suddenly [she]254-kitty saw the sky between two striped tree trunks extraordinarily blue . [She]254-kitty came out on the top . The wind ceased ; [the country]501-the country spread wide all round [her]254-kitty . [Her]254-kitty body seemed to shrink ; [her]254-kitty eyes to widen . [She]254-kitty threw [herself]254-kitty on the ground , and looked over [the billowing land that went rising and falling , away and away , until [somewhere far off]3770-somewhere far off [it]3769-the billowing land that went rising and falling , away and away , until somewhere far off it reached the sea reached [the sea]1514-the sea]3769-the billowing land that went rising and falling , away and away , until somewhere far off it reached the sea . Uncultivated , uninhabited , existing by [itself]3769-the billowing land that went rising and falling , away and away , until somewhere far off it reached the sea , for itself , without [towns]3772-towns or [houses]1311-houses [it]3769-the billowing land that went rising and falling , away and away , until somewhere far off it reached the sea looked from this height . Dark wedges of shadow , bright breadths of light lay side by side . Then , as [she]254-kitty watched , light moved and dark moved ; light and shadow went travelling over [the hills]2851-the hills and over [the valleys]2118-the valleys . A deep murmur sang in [her]254-kitty ears - [the land]500-the land itself , singing to itself , a chorus , alone . [She]254-kitty lay there listening . [She]254-kitty was happy , completely . Time had ceased .

1917

A very cold winter 's night , so silent that the air seemed frozen , and , since there was no moon , congealed to the stillness of glass spread over [England]35-england . [Ponds]3777-ponds and [ditches]3778-ditches were frozen ; the puddles made glazed eyes in [the roads]3779-the roads , and on the pavement the frost had raised slippery knobs . Darkness pressed on the windows ; [towns]3772-towns had merged [themselves]3772-towns in [open country]1312-open country . No light shone , save when a searchlight rayed round the sky , and stopped , here and there , as if to ponder some fleecy patch .

" If that is [the river]813-the river , "[276-eleanor] said [Eleanor]276-eleanor , pausing in [the dark street outside [the station]1884-the station]3782-the dark street outside the station , " [Westminster]19-westminster must be there . "[276-eleanor] [The omnibus in which [she]254-kitty had come , with its silent passengers]3784-the omnibus in which she had come , with its silent passengers looking cadaverous in the blue light , had already vanished . [She]254-kitty turned .

[She]254-kitty was dining with [Renny]389-renny and [Maggie]316-maggie , who lived in [one of [the obscure little streets under the shadow of the Abbey]3786-the obscure little streets under the shadow of the abbey]3785-one of the obscure little streets under the shadow of the abbey . [She]254-kitty walked on . The further side of [the street]587-the street was almost invisible . The lamps were shrouded in blue . [She]254-kitty flashed [her]254-kitty torch onto a name on [a street corner]3788-a street corner . Again [she]254-kitty flashed [her]254-kitty torch . Here it lit up a brick wall ; there a dark green tuft of ivy . At last the number thirty , the number [she]254-kitty was looking for , shone out . [She]254-kitty knocked and rang at the same moment , for the darkness seemed to muffle sound as well as sight . Silence weighed on [her]254-kitty as [she]254-kitty stood there waiting . Then the door opened and [a man]814-a man 's voice said , " Come in ! "[814-a man]

[He]814-a man shut the door behind [him]814-a man , quickly , as if to shut out the light . It looked strange after [the streets]1492-the streets - the perambulator in [the hall]638-the hall ; the umbrellas in the stand ; the carpet , the pictures : they all seemed intensified .

" Come in ! "[389-renny] said [Renny]389-renny again , and led [her]254-kitty into [the sitting - room]574-the sitting - room ablaze with light . [Another man]544-another man was standing in [the room]577-the room , and [she]254-kitty was surprised because [she]254-kitty had expected to find [them]3795-them alone .
